OSMUND: A fern of the genus Osmunda, or flowering fern. The mostremarkable species is the osmund royal, or royal fern (Osmundaregalis), which grows in wet or boggy places, and has large bipinnatefronds, often with a panicle of capsules at the top. The rootstockcontains much starch, and has been used in stiffening linen.
OTHERNESS: The quality or state of being other or different; alterity;oppositeness.
OARSMAN: One who uses, or is skilled in the use of, an oar; a rower.
OVERSHADE: To cover with shade; to render dark or gloomy; to overshadow.Shak.
OYSTER-GREEN: A green membranous seaweed (Ulva) often found growing onoysters but common on stones, piles, etc.
OUTVOTE: To exceed in the number of votes given; to defeat by votes.South.
OCCASIONALLY: In an occasional manner; on occasion; at times, as conveniencerequires or opportunity offers; not regularly. Stewart.The one, Wolsey, directly his subject by birth; the other, hissubject occasionally by his preferment. Fuller.
OVERREAD: To read over, or peruse. Shak.
OVIFEROUS: Egg-bearing; -- applied particularly to certain receptacles, asin Crustacea, that retain the eggs after they have been excluded fromthe formative organs, until they are hatched.
OBSTETRICIOUS: Serving to assist childbirth; obstetric; hence, facilitatingany bringing forth or deliverance. [Obs.]Yet is all human teaching but maieutical, or obstetricious. Cudworth.
ORTHOCLASE: Common or potash feldspar crystallizing in the monoclinicsystem and having two cleavages at right angles to each other. SeeFeldspar.
OENANTHOL: An oily substance obtained by the distillation of castor oil,recognized as the aldehyde of oenanthylic acid, and hence called alsooenanthaldehyde.
OSTEOGENETIC: Connected with osteogenesis, or the formation of bone;producing bone; as, osteogenetic tissue; the osteogenetic layer ofthe periosteum.
OPPUGNER: One who opposes or attacks; that which opposes. Selden.
OBLECTATION: The act of pleasing highly; the state of being greatly pleased;delight. [R.] Feltham.
OPUS: A work; specif. (Mus.), a musical composition.
OVERFRIEZE: To cover with a frieze, or as with a frieze. E. Hall.
ORTHOEPIST: One who is skilled in orthoëpy.
OSTEOPLASTY: An operation or process by which the total or partial loss of abone is remedied. Dunglison.
OSSUARY: A place where the bones of the dead are deposited; a charnelhouse. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
OBUMBRATION: Act of darkening or obscuring. [R.] Sir T. More.
OLIVASTER: Of the color of the olive; tawny. Sir T. Herbert.
OSTRICH: A large bird of the genus Struthio, of which Struthio camelusof Africa is the best known species. It has long and very stronglegs, adapted for rapid running; only two toes; a long neck, nearlybare of feathers; and short wings incapable of flight. The adult maleis about eight feet high.
OUTLAY: To lay out; to spread out; to display. [R.] Drayton.
ORDINABILITY: Capability of being ordained or appointed. [Obs.] Bp. Bull.
OBLATE: Flattened or depressed at the poles; as, the earth is an oblatespheroid.
OVERGIVE: To give over; to surrender; to yield. [Obs.] Spenser.
OPPILATE: To crowd together; to fill with obstructions; to block up.[Obs.] Cockeram.
OLEIC: Pertaining to, derived from, or contained in, oil; as, oleicacid, an acid of the acrylic acid series found combined with glycerylin the form of olein in certain animal and vegetable fats and oils,such as sperm oil, olive oil, etc. At low temperatures the acid iscrystalline, but melts to an oily liquid above 14
ORANGEROOT: An American ranunculaceous plant (Hidrastis Canadensis), havinga yellow tuberous root; -- also called yellowroot, golden seal, etc.
OXYGENATE: To unite, or cause to combine, with oxygen; to treat withoxygen; to oxidize; as, oxygenated water (hydrogen dioxide).
OMNIPREVALENT: Prevalent everywhere or in all things. Fuller.
ORTYGAN: One of several species of East Indian birds of the generaOrtygis and Hemipodius. They resemble quails, but lack the hind toe.See Turnix.
OSSEIN: The organic basis of bone tissue; the residue after removal ofthe mineral matters from bone by dilute acid; in embryonic tissue,the substance in which the mineral salts are deposited to form bone;-- called also ostein. Chemically it is the same as collagen.
OMITTANCE: The act of omitting, or the state of being omitted;forbearance; neglect. Shak.
ONE-HAND: Employing one hand; as, the one-hand alphabet. See Dactylology.
OVERWREST: To wrest or force from the natural or proper position. Shak.
OUNCE: The twelfth part of a troy pound.
OBTURATOR: An apparatus designed to close an unnatural opening, as afissure of the palate.
OLIGOCLASE: A triclinic soda-lime feldspar. See Feldspar.
OXIDIZE: To combine with oxygen, or subject to the action of oxygen, orof an oxidizing agent. Specifically:(a) To combine with oxygen or with more oxygen; to add oxygen to; as,to oxidize nitrous acid so as to form nitric acid.(b) To remove hydrogen from (anything), as by the action of oxygen;as, to oxidize alcohol so as to form aldehyde.(c) To subject to the action of oxygen or of an oxidizing agent, soas to bring to a higher grade, as an -ous compound to an -iccompound; as, to oxidize mercurous chloride to mercuric chloride.
OXYGENATION: The act or process of combining or of treating with oxygen;oxidation.
OSTEND: To exhibit; to manifest. [Obs.]Mercy to mean offenders we'll ostend. J. Webster.
ORTHODOXAL: Pertaining to, or evincing, orthodoxy; orthodox. [R.] Milton.
OLFACTORY: Of, pertaining to, or connected with, the sense of smell; as,the olfactory nerves; the olfactory cells. Olfactory organ (Anat.),an organ for smelling. In vertebrates the olfactory organs are moreor less complicated sacs, situated in the front part of the head andlined with epithelium innervated by the olfactory (or first cranial)nerves, and sensitive to odoriferous particles conveyed to it in theair or in water.
OVERMORROW: The day after or following to-morrow. [Obs.] Bible (1551).
OVIDUCT: A tube, or duct, for the passage of ova from the ovary to theexterior of the animal or to the part where further development takesplace. In mammals the oviducts are also called Fallopian tubes.
OBLONGATAL: Of or pertaining to the medulla oblongata; medullar.
OFFSHOOT: That which shoots off or separates from a main stem, channel,family, race, etc.; as, the offshoots of a tree.
OCULO-: A combining form from L. oculus the eye.
OVINE: Of or pertaining to sheep; consisting of sheep.
OPHIDIAN: One of the Ophidia; a snake or serpent.
ODONTORNITHES: A group of Mesozoic birds having the jaws armed with teeth, asin most other vertebrates. They have been divided into three orders:Odontolcæ, Odontotormæ, and Saururæ.
OPPUGN: To fight against; to attack; to be in conflict with; to oppose;to resist.They said the manner of their impeachment they could not but conceivedid oppugn the rights of Parliament. Clarendon.
OUT-PATIENT: A patient who is outside a hospital, but receives medical aidfrom it.
OVERSKIRT: An upper skirt, shorter than the dress, and usually draped.
OVULIST: A believer in the theory (called encasement theory), currentduring the last century, that the egg was the real animal germ, andthat at the time of fecundation the spermatozoa simply gave theimpetus which caused the unfolding of the egg, in which allgenerations were inclosed one within the other. Also called ovist.
OFT: Often; frequently; not rarely; many times. [Poetic] Chaucer.Oft she rejects, but never once offends. Pope.
OPINIATE: To hold or maintain persistently. [Obs.] Barrow.
OREODON: A genus of extinct herbivorous mammals, abundant in theTertiary formation of the Rocky Mountains. It is more or less relatedto the camel, hog, and deer.
ODONTALGIC: Of or pertaining to odontalgia.-- n.
OSTEOSARCOMA: A tumor having the structure of a sacroma in which there is adeposit of bone; sarcoma connected with bone.
OVERCARKING: Too anxious; too full of care. [Archaic] Fuller.
OTTAVA RIMA: A stanza of eight lines of heroic verse, with three rhymes, thefirst six lines rhyming alternately and the last two forming acouplet. It was used by Byron in "Don Juan," by Keats in "Isabella,"by Shelley in "The Witch of Atlas," etc.
OSTEOGEN: The soft tissue, or substance, which, in developing bone,ultimately undergoes ossification.
OUTSPAN: To unyoke or disengage, as oxen from a wagon. [S. Africa]
ORTHOXYLENE: That variety of xylene in which the two methyl groups are inthe ortho position; a colorless, liquid, combustible hydrocarbonresembling benzene.
OVERBATTLE: Excessively fertile; bearing rank or noxious growths. [Obs.]"Overbattle grounds." Hooker.
OPTIMIST: One who holds the opinion that all events are ordered for thebest.
ORIGIN: The point of attachment or end of a muscle which is fixedduring contraction; -- in contradistinction to insertion. Origin ofcoördinate axes (Math.), the point where the axes intersect. See Noteunder Ordinate.
OREOSELIN: A white crystalline substance which is obtained indirectly fromthe root of an umbelliferous plant (Imperatoria Oreoselinum), andyields resorcin on decomposition.
OUTBUILDING: A building separate from, and subordinate to, the main house;an outhouse.
OVERSET: To turn, or to be turned, over; to be upset. Mortimer.
OVERMATCH: One superior in power; also, an unequal match; a contest inwhich one of the opponents is overmatched. Milton. D. Webster.
OAK: Any tree or shrub of the genus Quercus. The oaks have alternateleaves, often variously lobed, and staminate flowers in catkins. Thefruit is a smooth nut, called an acorn, which is more or lessinclosed in a scaly involucre called the cup or cupule. There are nowrecognized about three hundred species, of which nearly fifty occurin the United States, the rest in Europe, Asia, and the other partsof North America, a very few barely reaching the northern parts ofSouth America and Africa. Many of the oaks form forest trees of grandproportions and live many centuries. The wood is usually hard andtough, and provided with conspicuous medullary rays, forming thesilver grain.
OCCIPUT: The back, or posterior, part of the head or skull; the regionof the occipital bone.
OVERRUN: To extend beyond its due or desired length; as, a line, oradvertisement, overruns.
OUTSEE: To see beyond; to excel in cer
OMINOUS: Of or pertaining to an omen or to omens; being or exhibiting anomen; significant; portentous; -- formerly used both in a favorableand unfavorable sense; now chiefly in the latter; foreboding orforeshowing evil; inauspicious; as, an ominous dread.He had a good ominous name to have made a peace. Bacon.In the heathen worship of God, a sacrifice without a heart wasaccounted ominous. South.-- Om"i*nous*ly, adv.-- Om"i*nous*ness, n.
ONERARY: Fitted for, or carrying, a burden. Johnson.
OSTRACION: A genus of plectognath fishes having the body covered withsolid, immovable, bony plates. It includes the trunkfishes.
OSCULANT: Adhering closely; embracing; -- applied to certain creepinganimals, as caterpillars.
ORNAMENTAL: Serving to ornament; characterized by ornament; beautifying;embellishing.Some think it most ornamental to wear their bracelets on theirwrists; others, about their ankles. Sir T. Browne.
OBSEQUIOUS: Of or pertaining to obsequies; funereal. [R.] "To do obsequioussorrow." Shak.
ORTHOSTICHY: A longitudinal rank, or row, of leaves along a stem.
OBLONGUM: A prolate spheroid; a figure described by the revolution of anellipse about its greater axis. Cf. Oblatum, and see Ellipsoid ofrevolution, under Ellipsoid.
OVER-STORY: The clearstory, or upper story, of a building.
OTOSCOPE: An instrument for examining the condition of the ear.
OBELION: The region of the skull between the two parietal foramina wherethe closure of the sagittal suture usually begins.
ORDONNANT: Of or pertaining to ordonnance. Dryden.
OBLIGABLE: Acknowledging, or complying with, obligation; trustworthy. [R.]The main difference between people seems to be, that one man can comeunder obligations on which you can rely, -- is obligable; and anotheris not. Emerson.
OFFICIAL: Approved by authority; sanctioned by the pharmacopoeia;appointed to be used in medicine; as, an official drug orpreparation. Cf. Officinal.
OTIOSE: Being at leisure or ease; unemployed; indolent; idle. "Otioseassent." Paley.The true keeping of the Sabbath was not that otiose and unAlford.
OVERWEENING: Unduly confident; arrogant; presumptuous; conceited.-- O`ver*ween"ingly, adv. Milton.-- O`ver*ween"ing*ness, n.Here's an overweening rogue. Shak.
OTOCRANE: The cavity in the skull in which the parts of the internal earare lodged.
ORTHOMETRY: The art or practice of constructing verses correctly; the lawsof correct versification.
ORIEL: A bay window. See Bay window.The beams that thro' the oriel shine Make prisms in every carvenglass. Tennyson.
OVERLEAD: To domineer over; to affront; to treat with indignity. [Obs.]Chaucer.
ORNITHOMANCY: Divination by means of birds, their flight, etc.Ornithomancy grew into an elaborate science. De Quincey.
OFFEND: To oppose or obstruct in duty; to cause to stumble; to cause tosin or to fall. [Obs.]Who hath you misboden or offended. Chaucer.If thy right eye offend thee, pluck it out... And if thy right handoffend thee, cut it off. Matt. v. 29, 3O.Great peace have they which love thy law, and nothing shall offendthem. Ps. cxix. 165.
OBSECRATION: A figure of speech in which the orator implores the assistanceof God or man.
OMELET: Eggs beaten up with a little flour, etc., and cooked in afrying pan; as, a plain omelet.
OVERPART: To give too important or difficult a part to. [Obs.] B. Jonson.
OLIVACEOUS: Resembling the olive; of the color of the olive; olive-green.
OPTOMETRIST: One who is skilled in or practices optometry.
OSTEOMA: A tumor composed mainly of bone; a tumor of a bone.
ORDERABLE: Capable of being ordered; tractable. [R.]Being very orderable in all his sickness. Fuller.
OXYQUINOLINE: Hydroxy quinoline; a phenol derivative of quinoline, -- calledalso carbostyril.
OPPOSITIPETALOUS: Placed in front of a petal.
OMISSIBLE: Capable of being omitted; that may be omitted.
ORYZA: A genus of grasses including the rice plant; rice.
OBEDIENT: Subject in will or act to authority; willing to obey;submissive to restraint, control, or command.And floating straight, obedient to the stream. Shak.The chief his orders gives; the obedient band, With due observance,wait the chief's command. Pope.
ORANG-OUTANG: An arboreal anthropoid ape (Simia satyrus), which inhabitsBorneo and Sumatra. Often called simply orang. [Written also orang-outan, orang-utan, ourang-utang, and oran-utan.]
OPISTHODOME: A back chamber; especially, that part of the naos, or cella,farthest from the main entrance, sometimes having an entrance of itsown, and often used as a treasury.
OBSECRATORY: Expressing, or used in, entreaty; supplicatory. [R.] Bp. Hall.
OVEREMPTY: To make too empty; to exhaust. [R.] Carew.
ORNATELY: In an ornate manner. Sir T. More.
OUTTALK: To overpower by talking; to exceed in talking; to talk down.Shak.
OSO-BERRY: The small, blueblack, drupelike fruit of the Nuttalliacerasiformis, a shrub of Oregon and California, belonging to theCherry tribe of Rosaceæ.
OLOGY: A colloquial or humorous name for any science or branch ofknowledge.He had a smattering of mechanics, of physiology, geology, mineralogy,and all other ologies whatsoever. De Quincey.
ORGANULE: One of the essential cells or elements of an organ. See Senseorganule, under Sense. Huxley.
OSCILLOGRAPH: An apparatus for recording or indicating alternating-currentwave forms or other electrical oscillations, usually consisting of agalvanometer with strong field, in which the mass of the moving partis very small and frequency of vibration very high. --Os`cil*lo*graph"ic (#), a.
OBJECTIST: One who adheres to, or is skilled in, the objective philosophy.Ed. Rev.
ORTHOTOMIC: Cutting at right angles. Orthotomic circle (Geom.), that circlewhich cuts three given circles at right angles.
OVERPICTURE: To surpass nature in the picture or representation of. [Obs.]"O'erpicturing that Venus." Shak.
ODINISM: Worship of Odin; broadly, the Teutonic heathenism. --O"din*ist, n.
OBSERVERSHIP: The office or work of an observer.
ODELSTHING: The lower house of the Norwegian Storthing. See Legislature.
OSTEOPOROSIS: An absorption of bone so that the tissue becomes unusuallyporous.
ODOROUS: Having or emitting an odor or scent, esp. a sweet odor;fragrant; sweet-smelling. "Odorous bloom." Keble.Such fragrant flowers do give most odorous smell. Spenser.-- O"dor*ous*ly, adv.-- O"dor*ous*ness, n.
ONCOTOMY: The opening of an abscess, or the removal of a tumor, with acutting instrument. [Written also onkotomy.] Dunglison.
ODDLY: In a manner measured by an odd number.
OBJECTOR: One who objects; one who offers objections to a proposition ormeasure.
OSMOMETER: An instrument for measuring the amount of osmotic action indifferent liquids.
OZONOMETRY: The measurement or determination of the quantity of ozone.
ONEIDAS: A tribe of Indians formerly inhabiting the region near OneidaLake in the State of New York, and forming part of the Five Nations.Remnants of the tribe now live in New York, Canada, and Wisconsin.
OVERLIVE: To outlive. Sir P. Sidney.The culture of Northumbria overlived the term of its politicalsupermacy. Earle.
OXIDATION: The act or process of oxidizing, or the state or result ofbeing oxidized.
OUTPUT: That which is thrown out as products of the metabolic activityof the body; the egesta other than the fæces. See Income.
OILMAN: One who deals in oils; formerly, one who dealt in oils andpickles.
OSSIVOROUS: Feeding on bones; eating bones; as, ossivorous quadrupeds.Derham.
OVATE-SUBULATE: Having an ovate form, but with a subulate tip or extremity.
OXYGENIC: Pertaining to, containing, or resembling, oxygen; producingoxygen.
OCTANE: Any one of a group of metametric hydrocarcons (C8H18) of themethane series. The most important is a colorless, volatile,inflammable liquid, found in petroleum, and a constituent of benzeneor ligroin.
OBJURGATION: The act of objurgating; reproof.While the good lady was bestowing this objurgation on Mr.Ben Allen.Dickens.With a strong objurgation of the elbow in his ribs. Landor.
OPEN-EYED: With eyes widely open; watchful; vigilant. Shak.
OPTATE: To choose; to wish for; to desire. [Obs.] Cotgrave.
OVERWAX: To wax or grow too rapindly or too much. [Obs.] R. ofGloucester.
OSNABURG: A species of coarse linen, originally made in Osnaburg,Germany.
OSTEOLITE: A massive impure apatite, or calcium phosphate.
ONTOGENETIC: Of or pertaining to ontogenesis; as, ontogenetic phenomena.-- On`to*ge*net"ic*al*ly, adv.
OBJECTIVELY: In the manner or state of an object; as, a determinate ideaobjectively in the mind.
OVERWEIGH: To exceed in weight; to overbalance; to weigh down. Drayton.Hooker.
ONEMENT: The state of being at one or reconciled. [Obs.] Bp. Hall.
OFFLET: A pipe to let off water.
OVERBID: To bid or offer beyond, or in excess of. Dryden.
OUTDOORS: Abread; out of the house; out of doors.
OVUM: A more or less spherical and transparent mass of granularprotoplasm, which by a process of multiplication and growth developsinto a mass of cells, constituting a new individual like the parent;an egg, spore, germ, or germ cell. See Illust. of Mycropyle.
OPPOSITELY: In a situation to face each other; in an opposite manner ordirection; adversely.Winds from all quarters oppositely blow. May.
OVEROFFICIOUS: Too busy; too ready to intermeddle; too officious. Collier.
OCEANOLOGY: That branch of science which relates to the ocean.
OBLIGATORINESS: The quality or state of being obligatory.
OVEREXQUISITE: Too exquisite; too exact or nice; too careful.
OBTUND: To reduce the edge, pungency, or violent action of; to dull; toblunt; to deaden; to quell; as, to obtund the acrimony of the gall.[Archaic] Harvey.They...have filled all our law books with the obtunding story oftheir suits and trials. Milton.
ONAGER: A military engine acting like a sling, which threw stones froma bag or wooden bucket, and was operated by machinery. Fairholt.
OXIDULATED: Existing in the state of a protoxide; -- said of an oxide. [R.]
OBTAINMENT: The act or process of obtaining; attainment. Milton.
OPISTHOGLYPHA: A division of serpents which have some of the posteriormaxillary teeth grooved for fangs.
ORCHIS: A genus of endogenous plants growing in the North Temperatezone, and consisting of about eighty species. They are perennialherbs growing from a tuber (beside which is usually found the lastyear's tuber also), and are valued for their showy flowers. SeeOrchidaceous.
OLEORESIN: A natural mixture of a terebinthinate oil and a resin.
OVERTRADING: The act or practice of buying goods beyond the means ofpayment; a glutting of the market.
OXIDIZER: An agent employed in oxidation, or which facilitates or bringsabout combination with oxygen; as, nitric acid, chlorine, bromine,etc., are strong oxidizers.
OSTIC: Pertaining to, or applied to, the language of the Tuscaroras,Iroquois, Wyandots, Winnebagoes, and a part of the Sioux Indians.Schoolcraft.
ORDINATION: The act of setting apart to an office in the Christianministry; the conferring of holy orders.
OCCULTISM: A certain Oriental system of theosophy. A. P. Sinnett.
OPPORTUNE: Convenient; ready; hence, seasonable; timely. Milton.This is most opportune to our need. Shak.-- Op`por*tune"ly, adv.-- Op`por*tune"ness, n.
OBLIGATION: A bond with a condition annexed, and a penalty fornonfulfillment. In a larger sense, it is an acknowledgment of a dutyto pay a certain sum or do a certain things. Days of obligation. Seeunder Day.
OPINATIVE: Obstinate in holding opinions; opinionated. [Obs.] --O*pin"a*tive*ly, adv. [Obs.] Burton. Sir T. More.
OMNIFY: To render universal; to enlarge. [R.]Omnify the disputed point into a transcendent, and you may defy theopponent to lay hold of it. Coleridge.
OXIDABLE: Capable of being converted into an oxide.
OPPOSITIVE: Capable of being put in opposition. Bp. Hall.
OCTOGENARIAN: A person eighty years, or more, of age.
OBTRUSIVE: Disposed to obtrude; inclined to intrude or thrust one's selfor one's opinions upon others, or to enter uninvited; forward;pushing; intrusive.-- Ob*tru"sive*ly, adv.-- Ob*tru"sive*ness, n.Not obvious, not obtrusive, but retired. Milton.
ORB: A blank window or panel. [Obs.] Oxf. Gloss.
OFFICEHOLDER: An officer, particularly one in the civil service; a placeman.
OPERCLE: Any one of the bony plates which support the gill covers offishes; an opercular bone.
OSTROGOTH: One of the Eastern Goths. See Goth.
OCCLUDENT: Serving to close; shutting up.-- n.
OBLATRATE: To bark or snarl, as a dog. [Obs.]
ORILLON: A semicircular projection made at the shoulder of a bastion forthe purpose of covering the retired flank, -- found in oldfortresses.
OE: a diphthong, employed in the Latin language, and thence in theEnglish language, as the representative of the Greek diphthong oe. Inmany words in common use, e alone stands instead of oe. Classicistsprefer to write the diphthong oe separate in Latin words.
OLD-WOMANISH: Like an old woman; anile.-- Old`-wom"an*ish*ness, n.
ORNITHOPODA: An order of herbivorous dinosaurs with birdlike characteristicsin the skeleton, esp. in the pelvis and hind legs, which in somegenera had only three functional toes, and supported the body inwalking as in Iguanodon. See Illust. in Appendix.
ORANGITE: An orange-yellow variety of the mineral thorite, found inNorway.
OUTRIDE: To surpass in speed of riding; to ride beyond or faster than.Shak.
OBSERVABLE: Worthy or capable of being observed; discernible; noticeable;remarkable. Sir. T. Browne.The difference is sufficiently observable. Southey.-- Ob*serv"a*ble*ness, n.-- Ob*serv"a*bly, adv.
OR: A particle that marks an alternative; as, you may read or maywrite, -- that is, you may do one of the things at your pleasure, butnot both. It corresponds to either. You may ride either to London orto Windsor. It often connects a series of words or propositions,presenting a choice of either; as, he may study law, or medicine, ordivinity, or he may enter into trade.If man's convenience, health, Or safety interfere, his rights andclaims Are paramount. Cowper.
OPINIONATED: Stiff in opinion; firmly or unduly adhering to one's ownopinion or to preconceived notions; obstinate in opinion. Sir W.Scott.
OUTJEST: To surpass in jesting; to drive out, or away, by jesting. [R.]Shak.
ORBITOSPHENOIDAL: Of or pertaining to the orbitosphenoid bone; orbitosphenoid.
ORIFICE: A mouth or aperture, as of a tube, pipe, etc.; an opening; as,the orifice of an artery or vein; the orifice of a wound. Shak.Etna was bored through the top with a monstrous orifice. Addison.
OMNIPATIENT: Capable of enduring all things. [R.] Carlyle.
OVERDRIVE: To drive too hard, or far, or beyond strength.
OVERBLOW: To force so much wind into a pipe that it produces an overtone,or a note higher than the natural note; thus, the upper octaves of aflute are produced by overblowing.
OUTMOST: Farthest from the middle or interior; farthest outward;outermost.
ORDINABLE: Capable of being ordained or appointed. [Obs.]
OBVENTION: The act of happening incidentally; that which happens casually;an incidental advantage; an occasional offering. [Obs.] "Tithes andother obventions." Spenser.Legacies bequeathed by the deaths of princes and great persons, andother casualities and obventions. Fuller.
OVERSPIN: To spin out to too great length; to protract unduly. W.Cartwright.
ORNITHOLOGIST: One skilled in ornithology; a student of ornithology; one whodescribes birds.
OBSERVANDUM: A thing to be observed. Swift.
OVERCAUTIOUS: Too cautious; cautious or prudent to excess.-- O"ver*cau"tious*ly, adv.-- O"ver*cau"tiou*ness, n.
OHM: The standard unit in the measure of electrical resistance,being the resistance of a circuit in which a potential difference ofone volt produces a current of one ampére. As defined by theInternational Electrical Congress in 1893, and by United StatesStatute, it is a resistance substantially equal to 109 units ofresistance of the C.G.S. system of electro-magnetic units, and isrepresented by the resistance offered to an unvarying electriccurrent by a column of mercury at the temperature of melting ice14.4521 grams in mass, of a constant cross-sectional area, and of thelength of 106.3 centimeters. As thus defined it is called theinternational ohm. Ohm's law (Elec.), the statement of the fact thatthe strength or intensity of an electrical current is directlyproportional to the electro-motive force, and inversely proportionalto the resistance of the circuit.
ORIGINATE: To give an origin or beginning to; to cause to be; to bringinto existence; to produce as new.A decomposition of the whole civill and political mass, for thepurpose of originating a new civil order. Burke.
OCCASIONALITY: Quality or state of being occasional; occasional occurrence.[R.]
OVERPROPORTION: To make of too great proportion.
OUTWIN: To win a way out of. [Obs.]
OLIVIL: A white crystalline substance, obtained from an exudation fromthe olive, and having a bitter-sweet taste and acid proporties.[Written also olivile.] Gregory.
O: A prefix to Irish family names, which signifies grandson ordescendant of, and is a character of dignity; as, O'Neil, O'Carrol.
OMER: A Hebrew measure, the tenth of an ephah. See Ephah. Ex. xvi.36.
ORTHOGONALLY: Perpendicularly; at right angles; as, a curve cuts a set ofcurves orthogonally.
OTOPATHY: A diseased condition of the ear.
OVERSHOE: A shoe that is worn over another for protection from wet or forextra warmth; esp., an India-rubber shoe; a galoche.
ORANGEMAN: One of a secret society, organized in the north of Ireland in1795, the professed objects of which are the defense of the regningsovereign of Great Britain, the support of the Protestant religion,the maintenance of the laws of the kingdom, etc.; -- so called inhonor of William, Prince of Orange, who became William III. ofEngland.
OBFUSCATE: Obfuscated; darkened; obscured. [Obs.] [Written alsooffuscate.] Sir. T. Elyot.
OCTOPUS: A genus of eight-armed cephalopods, including numerous species,some of them of large size. See Devilfish,
ODONTOGRAPH: An instrument for marking or laying off the outlines of teethof gear wheels.
OSSEOUS: Composed of bone; resembling bone; capable of forming bone;bony; ossific.
ORDOVICIAN: Of or pertaining to a division of the Silurian formation,corresponding in general to the Lower Silurian of most authors,exclusive of the Cambrian.-- n.
OLIVE: An olivary body. See under Olivary.
ODONTOPHORE: A special structure found in the mouth of most mollusks, exceptbivalves. It consists of several muscles and a cartilage whichsupports a chitinous radula, or lingual ribbon, armed with teeth.Also applied to the radula alone. See Radula.
OVULAR: Relating or belonging to an ovule; as, an ovular growth.
OWL: Any cpecies of raptorial birds of the family Strigidæ. Theyhave large eyes and ears, and a conspicuous circle of feathers aroundeach eye. They are mostly nocturnal in their habits.
OLIGIST: Hematite or specular iron ore; -- prob. so called in allusionto its feeble magnetism, as compared with magnetite.
ORNAMENT: That which embellishes or adorns; that which adds grace orbeauty; embellishment; decoration; adornment.The ornament of a meek and quiet spirit. 1 Pet. iii. 4.Like that long-buried body of the king Found lying with his urns andornaments. Tennyson.
ONONDAGAS: A tribe of Indians formerly inhabiting what is now a part ofthe State of New York. They were the central or head tribe of theFive Nations.
OUTPOWER: To excel in power; to overpover. [Obs.] Fuller.
OVERWORD: To say in too many words; to express verbosely. Hales.
OPPUGNANT: Tending to awaken hostility; hostile; opposing; warring."Oppugnant forces." I. Taylor.-- n.
OVERWORN: Worn out or subdued by toil; worn out so as to be trite.
OCTAGONAL: Having eight sides and eight angles.
OPENBILL: A bird of the genus Anastomus, allied to the stork; -- socalled because the two parts of the bill touch only at the base andtip. One species inhabits India, another Africa. Called also open-beak. See Illust. (m), under Beak.
ODONTOSTOMATOUS: Having toothlike mandibles; -- applied to certain insects.
ORLOP: The lowest deck of a vessel, esp. of a ship of war, consistingof a platform laid over the beams in the hold, on which the cablesare coiled.
OVATE-ROTUNDATE: Having a form intermediate between that of an egg and a sphere;roundly ovate.
OCTAHEDRON: A solid bounded by eight faces. The regular octahedron iscontained by eight equal equilateral triangles.
OPHTHALMITE: An eyestalk; the organ which bears the compound eyes of decapodCrustacea.
OSTENSIVE: Showing; exhibiting. Ostensive demonstration (Math.), a director positive demonstration, as opposed to the apagogical or indirectmethod.
OJO: A spring, surrounded by rushes or rank grass; an oasis.[Southwestern U.S.] Bartlett.
OVERBROW: To hang over like a brow; to impend over. [Poetic] Longfellow.Did with a huge projection overbrow Large space beneath. Wordsworth.
OVERPRIZE: Toprize excessively; to overvalue. Sir H. Wotton.
OUTBRAG: To surpass in bragging; hence, to make appear inferior.Whose bare outbragg'd the web it seemed to wear. Shak.
OPPUGNANCY: The act of oppugning; opposition; resistance. Shak.
OVERRAKE: To rake over, or sweep across, from end to end, as waves thatbreak over a vessel anchored with head to the sea.
OMMATEUM: A compound eye, as of insects and crustaceans.
OPHIURAN: Of or pertaining to the Ophiurioidea.-- n.
OVERQUELL: To quell or subdue completely. [R.] Bp. Hall.
OPAQUENESS: The state or quality of being impervious to light; opacity. Dr.H. More.
OBTENEBRATION: The act of darkening; the state of being darkened; darkness.[Obs.]In every megrim or vertigo, there is an obtenebration joined with asemblance of turning round. Bacon.
OXALETHYLINE: A poisonous nitrogenous base (C6H10N2) obtained indirectly fromoxamide as a thick transparent oil which has a strong narcotic odor,and a physiological action resembling that of atropine. It isprobably related to pyridine.
OPTOGRAM: An image of external objects fixed on the retina by thephotochemical action of light on the visual purple. See Optography.
OBITUARY: Of or pertaining to the death of a person or persons; as, anobituary notice; obituary poetry.
OVERPLUS: That which remains after a supply, or beyond a quantityproposed; surplus. Shak. "The overplus of a great fortune." Addison.
OCCURSION: A meeting; a clash; a collision. [Obs.] Boyle.
OBSIDIONAL: Of or pertaining to a siege. Obsidional crown (Rom.Antiq.), acrown bestowed upon a general who raised the siege of a beleagueredplace, or upon one who held out against a siege.
OBSTRINGE: To constrain; to put under obligation. [R.] Bp. Gardiner.
OPEIDOSCOPE: An instrument, consisting of a tube having one end open and theother end covered with a thin flexible membrance to the center ofwhich is attached a small mirror. It is used for exhibiting upon ascreen, by means of rays reflected from the mirror, the vibratorymotions caused by sounds produced at the open end of the tube, as byspeaking or singing into it. A. E. Dolbear.
OVERMUCHNESS: The quality or state of being in excess; superabundance. [R.]B. Jonson.
OUTROMANCE: To exceed in romantic character. [R.] Fuller.
OVERSHADOWER: One that throws a shade, or shadow, over anything. Bacon.
OBLATENESS: The quality or state of being oblate.
OENANTHYLOUS: Of, pertaining to, or designating, an acid formerly supposed tobe the acid of oenanthylic ether, but now known to be a mixture ofhigher acids, especially capric acid. [Obs.]
OVIDIAN: Of or pertaining to the Latin poet Ovid; resembling the styleof Ovid.
OVERREACH: The act of striking the heel of the fore foot with the toe ofthe hind foot; -- said of horses.
OVIFORM: Having the form or figure of an egg; egg-shaped; as, an oviformleaf.
OCTIC: Of the eighth degree or order.-- n. (Alg.)
OCTAVALENT: Having a valence of eight; capable of being combined with,exchanged for, or compared with, eight atoms of hydrogen; -- said ofcertain atoms or radicals.
OPTIMATE: Of or pertaining to the nobility or aristocracy. [R.] -- n.
OMNIFORMITY: The condition or quality of having every form. Dr. H. More.
OSTENSIBILITY: The quality or state of being ostensible.
OCTAVE: The first two stanzas of a sonnet, consisting of four verseseach; a stanza of eight lines.With mournful melody it continued this octave. Sir P. Sidney.Double octave. (Mus.) See under Double.-- Octave flute (Mus.), a small flute, the tones of which range anoctave higher than those of the German or ordinary flute; -- calledalso piccolo. See Piccolo.
ORCHIDACEOUS: Pertaining to, or resembling, a natural order (Orchidaceæ) ofendogenous plants of which the genus Orchis is the type. They aremostly perennial herbs having the stamens and pistils united in asingle column, and normally three petals and three sepals, alladherent to the ovary. The flowers are curiously shaped, oftenresembling insects, the odd or lower petal (called the lip) beingunlike the others, and sometimes of a strange and unexpectedappearance. About one hundred species occur in the United States, butseveral thousand in the tropics.
ORDAIN: To invest with ministerial or sacerdotal functions; tointroduce into the office of the Christian ministry, by the laying onof hands, or other forms; to set apart by the ceremony of ordination.Meletius was ordained by Arian bishops. Bp. Stillingfleet.
OFFING: That part of the sea at a good distance from the shore, orwhere there is deep water and no need of a pilot; also, distance fromthe shore; as, the ship had ten miles offing; we saw a ship in theoffing.
OVERHENT: To overtake. [Obs.]So forth he went and soon them overhent. Spenser.
OMNICORPOREAL: Comprehending or including all bodies; embracing all substance.[R.] Cudworth.
ORIGINAL: The natural or wild species from which a domesticated orcultivated variety has been derived; as, the wolf is thought by someto be the original of the dog, the blackthorn the original of theplum.
OVERDROWN: To wet or drench to excess. [Obs.] W. Browne.
ONTO: On the top of; upon; on. See On to, under On, prep.
OSTEOTOME: Strong nippers or a chisel for dividing bone.
OCTOIC: Pertaining to, derived from, or resembling, octane; -- usedspecifically, to designate any one of a group of acids, the mostimportant of which is called caprylic acid.
OVIDUCAL: Of or pertaining to oviducts; as, oviducal glands.
OUTSTORM: To exceed in storming.Insults the tempest and outstorms the skies. J. Barlow.
OCCULT: Hidden from the eye or the understanding; inviable; secret;concealed; unknown.It is of an occult kind, and is so insensible in its advances as toescape observation. I. Taylor.Occult line (Geom.), a line drawn as a part of the construction of afigure or problem, but not to appear in the finished plan.-- Occult qualities, those qualities whose effects only wereobserved, but the nature and relations of whose productive agencieswere undetermined; -- so called by the schoolmen.-- Occult sciences, those sciences of the Middle Ages which relatedto the supposed action or influence of occult qualities, orsupernatural powers, as alchemy, magic, necromancy, and astrology.
ORCHILLA WEED: The lichen from which archil is obtained. See Archil.
OCHROLEUCOUS: Yellowish white; having a faint tint of dingy yellow. Gray.
OVATE-LANCEOLATE: Having a form intermediate between ovate and lanceolate.
OMNIFARIOUS: Of all varieties, forms, or kinds. "Omnifarious learning."Coleridge.
ORIGINANT: Originating; original. [R.]An absolutely originant act of self will. Prof. Shedd.
OLEFIANT: Forming or producing an oil; specifically, designating acolorless gaseous hydrocarbon called ethylene. [Archaic]
OCULUS: A round window, usually a small one.
OLFACTION: The sense by which the impressions made on the olfactory organsby the odorous particles in the atmosphere are perceived.
OUTBID: To exceed or surpass in bidding.Prevent the greedy, and outbid the bold. Pope.
OVAL: Broadly elliptical. Oval chuck (Mech.), a lathe chuck soconstructed that work attached to it, and cut by the turning tool inthe usual manner, becomes of an oval form.
OVERDRAW: To make drafts upon or against, in excess of the proper amountor limit.
ORIENTAL: Of or pertaining to the orient or east; eastern; concerned withthe East or Orientalism; -- opposed to occidental; as, Orientalcountries.The sun's ascendant and oriental radiations. Sir T. Browne.
OVERPOWER: To excel or exceed in power; to cause to yield; to vanquish; tosubdue; as, the light overpowers the eyes. "And overpower'd thatgallant few." Wordsworth.
OVERBOW: To bend or bow over; to bend in a contrary direction. [Obs.]Fuller.
OUTGO: That which goes out, or is paid out; outlay; expenditure; --the opposite of Ant: income. Lowell.
OVERACT: To act more than is necessary; to go to excess in action. B.Jonson.
OSTEOLOGY: The science which treats of the bones of the vertebrateskeleton.
OPTIONAL: Involving an option; depending on the exercise of an option;left to one's discretion or choice; not compulsory; as, optionalstudies; it is optional with you to go or stay.-- n.
OBEISANT: Ready to obey; reverent; differential; also, servilelysubmissive.
OXYSALT: A salt of an oxyacid, as a sulphate.
OSTROGOTHIC: Of or pertaining to the Ostrogoths.
OVERNIGHT: The fore part of the night last past; the previous evening.[R.] Shak.
ORCADIAN: Of or pertaining to the Orkney Islands.
ORTHODIAGONAL: The diagonal or lateral axis in a monoclinic crystal which isat right angles with the vertical axis.
OVERLAYER: One who overlays; that with which anything is overlaid.
OUTPREACH: To surpass in preaching.And for a villain's quick conversion A pillory can outpreach aparson. Trumbull.
OBLIQUE-ANGLED: Having oblique angles; as, an oblique-angled triangle.
OPHIOLOGIST: One versed in the natural history of serpents.
OBLIGEE: The person to whom another is bound, or the person to whom abond is given. Blackstone.
OVERLIE: To lie over or upon; specifically, to suffocate by lying upon;as, to overlie an infant. Quain.A woman by negligence overlieth her child in her sleeping. Chaucer.
ORT: A morsel left at a meal; a fragment; refuse; -- commonly usedin the plural. Milton.Let him have time a beggar's orts to crave. Shak.
OTHEOSCOPE: An instrument for exhibiting the repulsive action produced bylight or heat in an exhausted vessel; a modification of theradoimeter. W. Crookes.
OUTLAST: To exceed in duration; to survive; to endure longer than.Milton.
OSMANLI: A Turkish official; one of the dominant tribe of Turks;loosely, any Turk.
OCCASIVE: Of or pertaining to the setting sun; falling; descending;western.
OPINIONATOR: An opinionated person; one given to conjecture. [Obs.] South.
OVERDO: To labor too hard; to do too much.
ODOMETRICAL: Of or pertaining to the odometer, or to measurements made withit.
OCULINA: A genus of tropical corals, usually branched, and having a veryvolid texture.
OVERCOUNT: To rate too high; to outnumber. Shak.
OPPOSITENESS: The quality or state of being opposite.
ORTHODOXICAL: Pertaining to, or evincing, orthodoxy; orthodox.
OCEANUS: The god of the great outer sea, or the river which was believedto flow around the whole earth.
OLEATE: A salt of oleic acid. Some oleates, as the oleate of mercury,are used in medicine by way of inunction.
OXYPHENOL: A phenol, oxyphenic acid, and now pyrocatechin.
OBVIOUS: Overlapping; contorted; convolute; -- applied primarily, inbotany, to two opposite leaves, each of which has one edgeoverlapping the nearest edge of the other, and secondarily to acircle of several leaves or petals which thus overlap.
OFFSKIP: That part of a landscape which recedes from the spectator intodistance. [R.] Fairholt.
OBLIQUENESS: Quality or state of being oblique.
ONTOLOGIST: One who is versed in or treats of ontology. Edin. Rev.
OB-: A prefix signifying to, toward, before, against, reversely,etc.; also, as a simple intensive; as in oblige, to bind to;obstacle, something standing before; object, lit., to throw against;obovate, reversely, ovate. Ob- is commonly assimilated before c, f,g, and p, to oc-, of-, og-, and op-.
OSTRACOID: Of or pertaining to the Ostracoidea.-- n.
OROGRAPHY: That branch of science which treats of mountains and mountainsystems; orology; as, the orography of Western Europe.
OBSTETRICIAN: One skilled in obstetrics; an accoucheur.
OROMETER: An aneroid barometer having a second scale that gives theapproximate elevation above sea level of the place where theobservation is made.
ORTHOLOGY: The right description of things. [R.] Fotherby.
OXYRRHODINE: A mixture of two parts of the oil of roses with one of thevinegar of roses. Floyer.
OSCULE: One of the excurrent apertures of sponges.
ORBITONASAL: Of or pertaining to the orbit and the nose; as, theorbitonasal, or ophthalmic, nerve.
OSTENSIBLY: In an ostensible manner; avowedly; professedly; apparently.Walsh.Ostensibly, we were intended to prevent filibustering into Texas, butreally as a menace to Mexico. U. S. Grant.
OPINIATIVE: Opinionative. Glanvill.-- O*pin"ia*tive*ly, adv.-- O*pin"ia*tive*ness, n.
OCULONASAL: Of or pertaining to the region of the eye and the nose; as, theoculonasal, or nasal, nerve, one of the branches of the ophthalmic.
OXAMETHANE: Ethyl oxamate, obtained as a white scaly crystalline powder.
OPPIDAN: Of or pertaining to a town. Howell.
OSMATE: A salt of osmic acid. [Formerly written also osmiate.]
OSCILLARIA: A genus of dark green, or purplish black, filamentous, fresh-water algæ, the threads of which have an automatic swaying orcrawling motion. Called also Oscillatoria.
ORBATION: The state of being orbate, or deprived of parents or children;privation, in general; bereavement. [Obs.] Bp. Hall.
OPTATIVELY: In an optative manner; with the expression of desire. [R.]God blesseth man imperatively, and man blesseth God optatively. Bp.Hall.
OLDNESS: The state or quality of being old; old age.
OLEAMEN: A soft ointment prepared from oil. Dunglison.
ORNATE: To adorn; to honor. [R.]They may ornate and sanctify the name of God. Latimer.
OVICULAR: Of or pertaining to an egg.
OSTRACIZE: To exile by ostracism; to banish by a popular vote, as atAthens. Grote.
OMPHALOPSYCHITE: A name of the Hesychasts, from their habit of gazing upon thenavel.
OMPHALO-: A combining form indicating connection with, or relation to,the umbilicus, or navel.
OVERSLOP: An outer garment, or slop. [Obs.] Chaucer.
ORIGINALNESS: The quality of being original; originality. [R.] Johnson.
OMNIETY: That which is all-pervading or all-comprehensive; hence, theDeity. [R.]Omniety formed nullity into an essence. Sir T. Browne.
OFFICIALLY: By the proper officer; by virtue of the proper authority; inpursuance of the special powers vested in an officer or office; as,accounts or reports officially vertified or rendered; lettersofficially communicated; persons officially notified.
OSSUARIUM: A charnel house; an ossuary. Walpole.
OMPHALOMANCY: Divination by means of a child's navel, to learn how manychildren the mother may have. Crabb.
OUTCROP: To come out to the surface of the ground; -- said of strata.
ORIENTATE: To move or turn toward the east; to veer from the north orsouth toward the east.
OPINIONED: Opinionated; conceited.His opinioned zeal which he thought judicious. Milton.
OGDOAD: A thing made up of eight parts. Milman.
OSMOGENE: An apparatus, consisting of a number of cells whose sides areof parchment paper, for conducting the process of osmosis. It is usedesp. in sugar refining to remove potassium salts from the molasses.
OILCLOTH: Cloth treated with oil or paint, and used for marking garments,covering flooors, etc.
OWNER: One who owns; a rightful proprietor; one who has the legal orrightful title, whether he is the possessor or not. Shak.
OVIPAROUS: Producing young from rggs; as, an oviparous animal, in whichthe egg is generally separated from the animal, and hatched afterexclusion; -- opposed to viviparous.
OBEY: To give obedience.Will he obey when one commands Tennyson.
ORATORIO: A more or less dramatic text or poem, founded on some Scripturenerrative, or great divine event, elaborately set to music, inrecitative, arias, grand choruses, etc., to be sung with anorchestral accompaniment, but without action, scenery, or costume,although the oratorio grew out of the Mysteries and the Miracle andPassion plays, which were acted.
OPERAMETER: An instrument or machine for measuring work done, especiallyfor ascertaining the number of rotations made by a machine or wheelin manufacturing cloth; a counter. Ure.
OVERAGITATE: To agitate or discuss beyond what is expedient. Bp. Hall.
OCCAMY: An alloy imitating gold or silver. [Written also ochimy,ochymy, etc.]
OARY: Having the form or the use of an oar; as, the swan's oary feet.Milton. Addison.
ORNITHOTOMY: The anatomy or dissection of birds.
OBTUNDENT: A substance which sheathes a part, or blunts irritation,usually some bland, oily, or mucilaginous matter; -- nearly the sameas demulcent. Forsyth.
OELET: An eye, bud, or shoot, as of a plant; an oilet. [Obs.] Holland.
OBDIPLOSTEMONOUS: Having twice as many stamens as petals, those of the outer setbeing opposite the petals; -- said of flowers. Gray.
OVERTITLE: To give too high a title to.
OSMOTIC: Pertaining to, or having the property of, osmose; as, osmoticforce.
OVERBUILT: Having too many buildings; as, an overbuilt part of a town.
OUNDING: Waving. [Obs.]Ounding, paling, winding, or bending . . . of cloth. Chaucer.
OBEDIENTIAL: According to the rule of obedience. [R.]An obediental subjection to the Lord of Nature. Sir M. Hale.
OLIGARCH: A member of an oligarchy; one of the rulers in an oligarchicalgovernment.
OZONOMETRIC: Pertaining to, or used for, the determination of the amount ofozone; of or relating to ozonometry.
OBSTACLE: That which stands in the way, or opposes; anything that hindersprogress; a hindrance; an obstruction, physical or moral.If all obstacles were cut away. And that my path were even to thecrown. Shak.
OVERTURNABLE: Capable of being, or liable to be, overturned or subverted.
ODYSSEY: An epic poem attributed to Homer, which describes the return ofUlysses to Ithaca after the siege of Troy.
OPOSSUM: Any American marsupial of the genera Didelphys and Chironectes.The common species of the United States is Didelphys Virginiana.
OWN: To grant; to acknowledge; to admit to be true; to confess; torecognize in a particular character; as, we own that we haveforfeited your love.The wakeful bloodhound rose, and shook his hide owns. Keats.
OSMIUM: A rare metallic element of the platinum group, found native asan alloy in platinum ore, and in iridosmine. It is a hard, infusible,bluish or grayish white metal, and the heaviest substance known. Itstetroxide is used in histological experiments to stain tissues.Symbol Os. Atomic weight 191.1. Specific gravity 22.477.
OLYMPIONIC: An ode in honor of a victor in the Olympic games. [R.] Johnson.
OCTILLION: According to the French method of numeration (which method isfollowed also in the United States) the number expressed by a unitwith twenty-seven ciphers annexed. According to the English method,the number expressed by a unit with forty-eight ciphers annexed. SeeNumeration.
OCA: A Peruvian name for certain species of Oxalis (O. crenata, andO. tuberosa) which bear edible tubers.
ORGANICALLY: In an organic manner; by means of organs or with reference toorganic functions; hence, fundamentally. Gladstone.
OVICYST: The pouch in which incubation takes place in some Tunicata.
OVULATION: The formation of ova or eggs in the ovary, and the discharge ofthe same. In the mammalian female the discharge occurs duringmenstruation.
OX: The male of bovine quadrupeds, especially the domestic animalwhen castrated and grown to its full size, or nearly so. The word isalso applied, as a general name, to any species of bovine animals,male and female.All sheep and oxen, yea, and the beasts of the field. Ps. viii. 7.
OVEREARNEST: Too earnest.-- O"ver*ear"nest*ly, adv.-- O"ver*ear"nest*ness, n.
OVERSUM: A sum or quantity over; surplus. [Obs.] Holinshed.
OWLING: The offense of transporting wool or sheep out of Englandcontrary to the statute formerly existing. Blackstone.
OPERCULAR: Of, pertaining to, or like, an operculum.
OOLONG: A fragrant variety of black tea having somewhat the flavor ofgreen tea. [Written also oulong.]
OPHIOMORPHOUS: Having the form of a serpent.
OVERWEARY: To weary too much; to tire out. Dryden.
OPHTHALMOLOGY: The science which treats of the structure, functions, anddiseases of the eye.
OBDUCE: To draw over, as a covering. [Obs.] Sir M. Hale.
ORPINE: A low plant with fleshy leaves (Sedum telephium), havingclusters of purple flowers. It is found on dry, sandy places, and onold walls, in England, and has become naturalized in America. Calledalso stonecrop, and live-forever. [Written also orpin.]
OVERKING: A king who has sovereignty over inferior kings or rulingprinces. J. R. Green.
OPPOSITIFOLIOUS: Placed at the same node with a leaf, but separated from it bythe whole diameter of the stem; as, an oppositifolious peduncle.
OXONIAN: Of or relating to the city or the university of Oxford,England. Macaulay.
OBITUARILY: In the manner of an obituary.
OBEDIENTLY: In an obedient manner; with obedience.
ORCIN: A colorless crystalline substance, C6H3.CH3.(OH)2, which isobtained from certain lichens (Roccella, Lecanora, etc.), also fromextract of aloes, and artificially from certain derivatives oftoluene. It changes readily into orcein.
OBUNCOUS: Hooked or crooked in an extreme degree. Maunder.
OXALITE: A yellow mineral consisting of oxalate of iron.
OUTPLAY: To excel or defeat in a game; to play better than; as, to beoutplayed in tennis or ball.
OCTA-: A prefix meaning eight. See Octo-.
OUTPRAY: To exceed or excel in prayer.
OBLITERATION: The act of obliterating, or the state of being obliterated;extinction. Sir. M. Hale.
ORTHOSPERMOUS: Having the seeds straight, as in the fruits of someumbelliferous plants; -- opposed to coelospermous. Darwin.
OUTSTART: To start out or up. Chaucer.
ORPHARION: An old instrument of the lute or cittern kind. [Spelt alsoorpheoreon.]
OTOBA FAT: A colorless buttery substance obtained from the fruit ofMyristica otoba, a species of nutmeg tree.
OPINICUS: An imaginary animal borne as a charge, having wings, an eagle'shead, and a short tail; -- sometimes represented without wings.
ORTHOCENTER: That point in which the three perpendiculars let fall from theangles of a triangle upon the opposite sides, or the sides produced,mutually intersect.
OUTLINEAR: Of or pertaining to an outline; being in, or forming, anoutline. Trench.
OLIGOCHAETA: An order of Annelida which includes the earthworms and relatedspecies.
OUTGUSH: A pouring out; an outburst.A passionate outgush of emotion. Thackeray.
OLIGARCHIST: An advocate or supporter of oligarchy.
OVERPRAISING: The act of praising unduly; excessive praise. Milton.
OVER: Upper; covering; higher; superior; also, excessive; too much ortoo great; -- chiefly used in composition; as, overshoes, overcoat,over-garment, overlord, overwork, overhaste.
OSCITATION: The act of yawning or gaping. Addison.
ORPHEAN: Of or pertaining to Orpheus, the mythic poet and musician; as,Orphean strains. Cowper.
OVEREXCITEMENT: Excess of excitement; the state of being overexcited.
OCCULTED: Concealed by the intervention of some other heavenly body, as astar by the moon.
ODE: A short poetical composition proper to be set to music or sung;a lyric poem; esp., now, a poem characterized by sustained noblesentiment and appropriate dignity of style.Hangs odes upon hawthorns and elegies on brambles. Shak.O! run; prevent them with thy humble ode, And lay it lowly at hisblessed feet. Milton.Ode factor, one who makes, or who traffics in, odes; -- usedcontemptuously.
OUTLOOSE: A loosing from; an escape; an outlet; an evasion. [Obs.]That "whereas" gives me an outloose. Selden.
OLYMPIAD: A period of four years, by which the ancient Greeks reckonedtime, being the interval from one celebration of the Olympic games toanother, beginning with the victory of Coroebus in the foot race,which took place in the year 776 b.c.; as, the era of the olympiads.
ORCHESTRION: A large music box imitating a variety of orchestralinstruments.
OLIVED: Decorated or furnished with olive trees. [R.] T. Warton.
OLECRANAL: Of or pertaining to the olecranon.
OH: An exclamation expressing various emotions, according to thetone and manner, especially surprise, pain, sorrow, anxiety, or awish. See the Note under O.
OXSHOE: A shoe for oxen, consisting of a flat piece of iron nailed tothe hoof.
OXTONGUE: A name given to several plants, from the shape and roughness oftheir leaves; as, Anchusa officinalis, a kind of bugloss, andHelminthia echioides, both European herbs.
ORION: A large and bright constellation on the equator, between thestars Aldebaran and Sirius. It contains a remarkable nebula visibleto the naked eye.The flaming glories of Orion's belt. E. Everett.
ORNITHOTOMIST: One who is skilled in ornithotomy.
OARSWEED: Any large seaweed of the genus Laminaria; tangle; kelp.  SeeKelp.
OUPHE: A fairy; a goblin; an elf. [Obs.] "Like urchins, ouphes, andfairies." Shak.
OVERINFLUENCE: To influence in an excessive degree; to have undue influenceover.
OUTDWELLER: One who holds land in a parish, but lives elsewhere. [Eng.]
OVERREADY: Too ready.-- O"ver*read"*i*ly, adv.-- O"ver*read"i*ness, n.
OUTRE: Being out of the common course or limits; extravagant; bizarre.
OBSIGN: To seal; to confirm, as by a seal or stamp. [Obs.] Bradford.
OENANTHYL: A hydrocarbon radical formerly supposed to exist in oenanthicacid, now known to be identical with heptyl.
OVERTHWARTLY: In an overthwart manner;across; also, perversely. [Obs.]Peacham.
OPISTHION: The middle of the posterior, or dorsal, margin of the greatforamen of the skull.
OFFICIALTY: The charge, office, court, or jurisdiction of an official.Ayliffe.
OXYMORON: A figure in which an epithet of a contrary signification isadded to a word; e. g., cruel kindness; laborious idleness.
ORECTIC: Of or pertaining to the desires; hence, impelling togratification; appetitive.
ORBICULATE: That which is orbiculate; especially, a solid the verticalsection of which is oval, and the horizontal section circular.
OBSTRUCTIONISM: The act or the policy of obstructing progress. Lond. Lit.World.
OVERDRESS: To dress or adorn to excess; to dress too much. Pope.
OLIGOMYOLD: Having few or imperfect syringeal muscles; -- said of somepasserine birds (Oligomyodi).
OCTAEMERON: A fast of eight days before a great festival. Shipley.
OBROGATE: To annul indirectly by enacting a new and contrary law, insteadof by expressly abrogating or repealing the old one. [Obs.] Bailey.
OUTSPOKEN: Speaking, or spoken, freely, openly, or boldly; as, anoutspoken man; an outspoken rebuke.-- Out*spo"ken*ness, n.
OUTCLIMB: To climb bevond; to surpass in climbing. Davenant.
OPHIOPHAGOUS: Feeding on serpents; -- said of certain birds and reptiles.
OVERTROW: To be too trustful or confident; to trust too much. [Obs.]Wyclif
ORTHOCERAS: An extinct genus of Paleozoic Cephalopoda, having a long,straight, conical shell. The interior is divided into numerouschambers by transverse septa.
ORDINAL: The book of forms for making, ordaining, and consecratingbishops, priests, and deacons.
OLYMPIANISM: Worship of the Olympian gods, esp. as a dominant cult orreligion.
OSMOMETRY: The study of osmose by means of the osmometer.
OUTLIE: To exceed in lying. Bp. Hall.
OSTEOCLASIS: The operation of breaking a bone in order to correct deformity.
OVERBOARD: Over the side of a ship; hence, from on board of a ship, intothe water; as, to fall overboard. To throw overboard, to discard; toabandon, as a dependent or friend.
OPSONATION: A catering; a buying of provisions. [Obs.] Bailey.
OUTNOISE: To exceed in noise; to surpass in noisiness. [R.] Fuller.
OATH: An appeal (in verification of a statement made) to a superiorsanction, in such a form as exposes the party making the appeal to anindictment for perjury if the statement be false.
OSSIFY: To form into bone; to change from a soft animal substance intobone, as by the deposition of lime salts.
OUTER: Being on the outside; external; farthest or farther from theinterior, from a given station, or from any space or positionregarded as a center or starting place; -- opposed to inner; as, theouter wall; the outer court or gate; the outer stump in cricket; theouter world. Outer bar, in England, the body of junior (or utter)barristers; -- so called because in court they occupy a place beyondthe space reserved for Queen's counsel.
ONLY: Save or except (that); -- an adversative used elliptically withor without that, and properly introducing a single fact orconsideration.He might have seemed some secretary or clerk . . . only that his low,flat, unadorned cap . . . indicated that he belonged to the city. SirW. Scott.
OBSOLESCENT: Going out of use; becoming obsolete; passing into desuetude.
OVERSEER: One who oversees; a superintendent; a supervisor; as, anoverseer of a mill; specifically, one or certain public officers; as,an overseer of the poor; an overseer of highways.
ORACLE: The sanctuary, or Most Holy place in the temple; also, thetemple itself. 1 Kings vi. 19.Siloa's brook, that flow'd Fast by the oracle of God. Milton.
OWHER: Anywhere. [Obs.] "If he found owher a good fellow." Chaucer.
OUTSAIL: To excel, or to leave behind, in sailing; to sail faster than.Beau. & Fl.
OPERAND: The symbol, quantity, or thing upon which a mathematicaloperation is performed; -- called also faciend.
OVERLEARNED: Too learned.-- O"ver*learn"ed, adv.-- O"ver*learn"ed*ness, n.
OSSICLE: One of numerous small calcareous structures forming theskeleton of certain echinoderms, as the starfishes.
ORBULINA: A genus of minute living Foraminifera having a globular shell.
OUTSLIDE: To slide outward, onward, or forward; to advance by sliding.[Poetic]At last our grating keels outslide. Whittier.
OLIGOMEROUS: Having few members in each set of organs; as, an oligomerousflower.
ONION: A liliaceous plant of the genus Allium (A.cepa), having astrong-flavored bulb and long hollow leaves; also, its bulbous root,much used as an article of food. The name is often extended to otherspecies of the genus. Onion fish (Zoöl.), the grenadier.-- Onion fly (Zoöl.) a dipterous insect whose larva feeds upon theonion; especially, Anthomyia ceparum and Ortalis flexa.-- Welsh onion. (Bot.) See Cibol.-- Wild onion (Bot.), a name given to several species of the genusAllium.
OPIFICER: An artificer; a workman. [Obs.] "The almighty opificer."Bentley.
OPTATION: The act of optating; a wish. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
OMPHACINE: Of, pertaining to, or expressed from, unripe fruit; as,omphacine oil.
OVERFILL: To fill to excess; to surcharge.
ORTHITE: A variety of allanite occurring in slender prismatic crystals.
OTACOUSTIC: Assisting the sense of hearing; as, an otacoustic instrument.
OBDURACY: The duality or state of being obdurate; invincible hardness ofheart; obstinacy. "Obduracy and persistency." Shak.The absolute completion of sin in final obduracy. South.
ONDOYANT: Wavy; having the surface marked by waves or slightly depressedfurrows; as, ondoyant glass.
OBSOLETE: Not very distinct; obscure; rudimental; imperfectly developed;abortive.
OUTREIGN: To go beyond in reigning; to reign through the whole of, orlonger than. [R.] Spenser.
ORTHOPTEROUS: Of or pertaining to the Orthoptera.
OXBANE: A poisonous bulbous plant (Buphane toxicaria) of the Cape ofGood Hope.
OCTOSTICHOUS: In eight vertical ranks, as leaves on a stem.
ORTIVE: Of or relating to the time or act of rising; eastern; as, theortive amplitude of a planet.
OCCIPITO-: A combining form denoting relation to, or situation near, theocciput; as, occipito-axial; occipito-mastoid.
ORFGILD: Restitution for cattle; a penalty for taking away cattle.Cowell.
OPPLETION: The act of filling up, or the state of being filled up;fullness. [Obs.]
OVERSHAKE: To shake over or away; to drive away; to disperse. [Obs.]Chaucer.
OBSTRICTION: The state of being constrained, bound, or obliged; that whichconstrains or obliges; obligation; bond. [R.] Milton.
OVERTIRE: To tire to excess; to exhaust.
OARLOCK: The notch, fork, or other device on the gunwale of a boat, inwhich the oar rests in rowing.  See Rowlock.
OCCLUDE: To take in and retain; to absorb; -- said especially withrespect to gases; as iron, platinum, and palladium occlude largevolumes of hydrogen.
OVERTURE: A composition, for a full orchestra, designed as anintroduction to an oratorio, opera, or ballet, or as an independentpiece; -- called in the latter case a concert overture.
OVERLINGER: To cause to linger; to detain too long. [Obs.] Fuller.
OATHBREAKING: The violation of an oath; perjury. Shak
OVERHARDEN: To harden too much; to make too hard. Boyle.
OUTBABBLE: To utter foolishly or excessively; to surpass in babbling. [R.]Milton.
ORDALIAN: Of or pertaining to trial by ordeal. [Obs.] Bp. Hall.
ORBICULAR: Resembling or having the form of an orb; spherical; circular;orbiculate.-- Or*bic"u*lar*ly, adv.-- Or*bic"u*lar*ness, n.Orbicular as the disk of a planet. De Quincey.
ORLE: A bearing, in the form of a fillet, round the shield, within,but at some distance from, the border.
OVERGRASSED: Overstocked, or overgrown, or covered, with grass. [Obs.]Spenser.
OUTMEASURE: To exceed in measure or extent; to measure more than. Sir T.Browne.
OVERARCH: To make or place an arch over; to hang over like an arch."Brown with o'erarching shades." Pope.
OWELTY: Equality; -- sometimes written ovelty and ovealty. Burrill.
OUTCRIER: One who cries out or proclaims; a herald or crier.
OSTENTATE: To make an ambitious display of; to show or exhibit boastingly.[R.] Jer. Taylor.
OSAGE ORANGE: An ornamental tree of the genus Maclura (M. aurantiaca),closely allied to the mulberry (Morus); also, its fruit. The tree wasfirst found in the country of the Osage Indians, and bears a hard andinedible fruit of an orangelike appearance. See Bois d'arc.
ORATOR: An officer who is the voice of the university upon all publicoccasions, who writes, reads, and records all letters of a publicnature, presents, with an appropriate address, those persons on whomhonorary degrees are to be conferred, and performs other like duties;-- called also public orator.
OSTEOMALACIA: A disease of the bones, in which they lose their earthymaterial, and become soft, flexible, and distorted. Also calledmalacia.
ORANGERY: A place for raising oranges; a plantation of orange trees.
OUTTONGUE: To silence by talk, clamor, or noise. [R.] Shak.
OVERHEAD: Aloft; above; in or attached to the ceiling or roof; in thestory or upon the floor above; in the zenith.While overhead the moon Sits arbitress. Milton.
OXYMETHYLENE: Formic aldehyde, regarded as a methylene derivative.
OPPROBRIUM: Disgrace; infamy; reproach mingled with contempt; abusivelanguage.Being both dramatic author and dramatic performer, he found himselfheir to a twofold opprobrium. De Quincey.
ORDUROUS: Of or pertaining to ordure; filthy. Drayton.
OLIBANUM: The fragrant gum resin of various species of Boswellia;Oriental frankincense.
OSCAN: Of or pertaining to the Osci, a primitive people of Campania, aprovince of ancient Italy.-- n.
OBDUCTION: .The act of drawing or laying over, as a covering. [Obs.]
OSCILLATING: That oscillates; vibrating; swinging. Oscillating engine, asteam engine whose cylinder oscillates on trunnions instead of beingpermanently fixed in a perpendicular or other direction. Weale.
OBELIZE: To designate with an obelus; to mark as doubtful or spirituous.[R.]
OXYBROMIC: Pertaining to, or designating, certain compounds of oxygen andbromine.
OVERLASH: To drive on rashly; to go to excess; hence, to exaggerate; toboast. [Obs.] Barrow.
OSCULATION: The contact of one curve with another, when the number ofconsecutive points of the latter through which the former passessuffices for the complete determination of the former curve. Brande &C.
OGREISH: Resembling an ogre; having the character or appearance of anogre; suitable for an ogre. "An ogreish kind of jocularity." Dickens.
OBJURGATORY: Designed to objurgate or chide; containing or expressingreproof; culpatory. Bancroft.The objurgatory question of the Pharisees. Paley.
OMNIFORM: Having every form or shape. Berkeley.
OUTGENERAL: To exceed in generalship; to gain advantage over by superiormilitary skill or executive ability; to outmaneuver. Chesterfield.
OPULENT: Having a large estate or property; wealthy; rich; affluent; as,an opulent city; an opulent citizen.-- Op"u*lent*ly, adv.I will piece Her opulent throne with kingdoms. Shak.
OVERSHOT: From Overshoot, v. t. Overshot wheel, a vertical water wheel,the circumference of which is covered with cavities or buckets, andwhich is turned by water which shoots over the top of it, filling thebuckets on the farther side and acting chiefly by its we'ght.
ORMUZD: The good principle, or being, of the ancient Persian religion.See Ahriman.
ORATION: An elaborate discourse, delivered in public, treating animportant subject in a formal and dignified manner; especially, adiscourse having reference to some special occasion, as a funeral, ananniversary, a celebration, or the like; -- distinguished from anargument in court, a popular harangue, a sermon, a lecture, etc.; as,Webster's oration at Bunker Hill.The lord archbishop . . . made a long oration. Bacon.
OUTBREAK: A bursting forth; eruption; insurrection. "Mobs and outbreaks."J. H. Newman.The flash and outbreak of a fiery mind. Shak.
OMNIVORA: A group of ungulate mammals including the hog and thehippopotamus. The term is also sometimes applied to the bears, and tocertain passerine birds.
OVERMARCH: To march too far, or too much; to exhaust by marching. Baker.
OVISM: The old theory that the egg contains the whole embryo of thefuture organism and the germs of all subsequent offsprings and ismerely awakened to activity by the spermatozoön; -- opposed tospermism or animalculism.
ORTHIS: An extinct genus of Brachiopoda, abundant in the Paleozoicrocks.
OBREPTITIOUS: Done or obtained by surprise; with secrecy, or by concealmentof the truth. [R.] Cotgrave.
ONDOGRAPH: An instrument for autographically recording the wave forms ofvarying currents, esp. rapidly varying alternating currents.
OUTLIER: A part of a rock or stratum lying without, or beyond, the mainbody, from which it has been separated by denudation.
OZONOSCOPE: An apparatus employed to indicate the presence, or the amount,of ozone.
OBSCURITY: The quality or state of being obscure; darkness; privacy;inconspicuousness; unintelligibleness; uncertainty.Yuo are not for obscurity designed. Dryden.They were now brought forth from obscurity, to be contemplated byartists with admiration and despair. Macaulay.
OVERTHWART: Across; crosswise; transversely. "Y'clenched overthwart andendelong." Chaucer.
ORNITHOPAPPI: An extinct order of birds. It includes only the Archæopteryx.
OBFIRMATION: Hardness of heart; obduracy. [Obs.] Jer. Taylor.
OSSIFIC: Capable of producing bone; having the power to change cartilageor other tissue into bone.
OENOCYAN: The coloring matter of red wines.
OPISTHOTONOS: A tetanic spasm in which the body is bent backwards andstiffened.
OVERGROUND: Situated over or above ground; as, the overground portion of aplant.
OCULARLY: By the eye, or by actual sight.
OCULAR: Of or pertaining to the eye; optic.
ONAPPO: A nocturnal South American monkey (Callithrix discolor), notedfor its agility; -- called also ventriloquist monkey.
OVERBALANCE: Excess of weight or value; something more than an equivalent;as, an overbalance of exports. J. Edwards.
ORPHAN: A child bereaved of both father and mother; sometimes, also, achild who has but one parent living. Orphans' court (Law), a court insome of the States of the Union, having jurisdiction over the estatesand persons of orphans or other wards. Bouvier.
OUTRUN: To exceed, or leave behind, in running; to run faster than; tooutstrip; to go beyond.Your zeal outruns my wishes. Sir W. Scott.The other disciple did outrun Peter, and came first to the sepulcher.Jhon xx. 4.
OTHERWHERE: In or to some other place, or places; elsewhere. Milton.Tennyson.
ORBITOLITES: A genus of living Foraminifera, forming broad, thin, circulardisks, containing numerous small chambers.
OCYPODIAN: One of a tribe of crabs which live in holes in the sand alongthe seashore, and run very rapidly, -- whence the name.
OSCILLOSCOPE: An instrument for showing visually the changes in a varyingcurrent; an oscillograph.
OVERPERSUADE: To persuade or influence against one's inclination or judgment.Pope.
OPTIMISM: The opinion or doctrine that everything in nature, being thework of God, is ordered for the best, or that the ordering of thingsin the universe is such as to produce the highest good.
OIDIUM: A genus of minute fungi which form a floccose mass of filamentson decaying fruit, etc. Many forms once referred to this genus arenow believed to be temporary conditions of fungi of other genera,among them the vine mildew (Oïdium Tuckeri), which has caused muchinjury to grapes.
OXHEAD: Literally, the head of an ox (emblem of cuckoldom); hence, adolt; a blockhead.Dost make a mummer of me, oxhead Marston.
OLIVIN: A complex bitter gum, found on the leaves of the olive tree; --called also olivite.
OUTSCOUT: To overpower by disdain; to outface. [Obs.] Marston.
OTOSCOPY: The examination of the ear; the art of using the otoscope.
OVIPOSITOR: The organ with which many insects and some other animalsdeposit their eggs. Some ichneumon files have a long ovipositorfitted to pierce the eggs or larvæ of other insects, in order to laytheir own eggs within the same.
OMENTUM: A free fold of the peritoneum, or one serving to connectviscera, support blood vessels, etc.; an epiploön.
OBLIQUELY: In an oblique manner; not directly; indirectly. "Truthobliquely leveled." Bp. Fell.Declining from the noon of day, The sun obliquely shoots his burningray. PopeHis discourse tends obliquely to the detracting from others. Addison.
OXYHYDROGEN: Of or pertaining to a mixture of oxygen and hydrogen; as,oxyhydrogen gas. Oxyhydrogen blowpipe. (Chem.) See Blowpipe.-- Oxyhydrogen microscope, a form of microscope arranged so as touse the light produced by burning lime or limestone under a currentof oxyhydrogen gas.
OMENTAL: Of or pertaining to an omentum or the omenta.
OUTWALL: The exterior wall; the outside surface, or appearance. Shak.
ORPIMENT: Arsenic sesquisulphide, produced artificially as an amorphouslemonyellow powder, and occurring naturally as a yellow crystallinemineral; -- formerly called auripigment. It is used in king's yellow,in white Indian fire, and in certain technical processes, as indigoprinting.Our orpiment and sublimed mercurie. Chaucer.Red orpiment, realgar; the red sulphide of arsenic.-- Yellow orpiment, king's yellow.
OVERHASTY: Too hasty; precipitate; rash.-- O"ver*has"ti*ly, adv.-- O`ver*has"ti*ness, n.
ORACULOUS: Oracular; of the nature of an oracle. [R.] "Equivocations, ororaculous speeches." Bacon. "The oraculous seer." Pope.-- O*rac"u*lous*ly, adv.-- O*rac"u*lous*ness, n.
OMOHYOID: Of or pertaining to the shoulder and the hyoid bone; as, theomohyoid muscle.
ORGANIC: Of or pertaining to an organ or its functions, or to objectscomposed of organs; consisting of organs, or containing them; as, theorganic structure of animals and plants; exhibiting characterspeculiar to living organisms; as, organic bodies, organic life,organic remains. Cf. Inorganic.
OPEN-AIR: Taking place in the open air; outdoor; as, an open-air game ormeeting.
OSCILLATORY: Moving, or characterized by motion, backward and forward like apendulum; swinging; oscillating; vibratory; as, oscillatory motion.
OUTBUILD: To exceed in building, or in durability of building.
OUTCOME: That which comes out of, or follows from, something else;issue; result; consequence; upshot. "The logical outcome." H.Spenser.All true literature, all genuine poetry, is the direct outcome, thecondensed essence, of actual life and thougth. J. C. Shairp.
OUTSCORN: To confront, or subdue, with greater scorn. Shak.
OVERSEE: To see too or too much; hence, to be deceived. [Obs.]The most expert gamesters may sometimes oversee. Fuller.Your partiality to me is much overseen, if you think me fit tocorrect your Latin. Walpole.
OPINATION: The act of thinking; a supposition. [Obs.]
OSPHRADIUM: The olfactory organ of some Mollusca. It is connected with theorgan of respiration.
ORE: Honor; grace; favor; mercy; clemency; happy augry. [Obs.]Chaucer.
OVEREAGER: Too eager; too impatient.-- O`ver*ea"ger*ly, adv.-- O"ver*ea"ger*ness, n.
OVERSAY: To say over; to repeat. Ford.
ONOMATECHNY: Prognostication by the letters of a name.
OBTUNDER: That which obtunds or blunts; especially, that which bluntssensibility.
OTOCYST: An auditory cyst or vesicle; one of the simple auditory organsof many invertebrates, containing a fluid and otoliths; also, theembryonic vesicle from which the parts of the internal ear ofvertebrates are developed.
OLEOSITY: The state or quality of being oily or fat; fatness. [R.] B.Jonson.
OVERJOY: To make excessively joyful; to gratify extremely.
OECOID: The colorless porous framework, or stroma, of red bloodcorpuscles from which the zooid, or hemoglobin and other substancesof the corpuscles, may be dissolved out.
ORCHESTRATION: The arrangement of music for an orchestra; orchestral treatmentof a composition; -- called also instrumentation.
OLD-GENTLEMANLY: Pertaining to an old gentleman, or like one. Byron.
OSTEO-: A combining form of Gr. a bone.
OBOLE: A weight of twelve grains; or, according to some, of tengrains, or half a scruple. [Written also obol.]
OPTIMITY: The state of being best. [R.] Bailey.
OBLIGATORY: Binding in law or conscience; imposing duty or obligation;requiring performance or forbearance of some act; -- often followedby on or upon; as, obedience is obligatory on a soldier.As long as the law is obligatory, so long our obedience is due. Jer.Taylor.
OSTEOSCLEROSIS: Abnormal hardness and density of bone.
OXYNTIC: Acid; producing acid; -applied especially to certain glands andcells in the stomach.
OVIPARA: An artifical division of vertebrates, including those that layeggs; -opposed to Vivipara.
OUTGAZE: To gaze beyond; to exceed in sharpness or persistence of seeingor of looking; hence, to stare out of countenance.
ORTHOGNATHOUS: Having the front of the head, or the skull, nearlyperpendicular, not retreating backwards above the jaws; -- opposed toAnt: prognathous. See Gnathic index, under Gnathic.
OPHTHALMOMETER: An instrument devised by Helmholtz for measuring the size of areflected image on the convex surface of the cornea and lens of theeye, by which their curvature can be ascertained.
OUTSHOOT: To exceed or excel in shooting; to shoot beyond. Bacon.Men are resolved never to outshoot their forefathers' mark. Norris.
ONOMASTIC: Applied to a signature when the body of the instrument is inanother's handwriting. Burrill.
OVERINFORM: To inform, fill, or animate, excessively. [R.] Johnson.
OMOSTERNAL: Of or pertaining to the omosternum.
ODORAMENT: A perfume; a strong scent. [Obs.] Burton.
OUAKARI: Any South American monkey of the genus Brachyurus, especiallyB. ouakari.
OVERMANNER: In an excessive manner; excessively. [Obs.] Wiclif.
OLIGOSIDERITE: A meteorite characterized by the presence of but a small amountof metallic iron.
OUTSKIRT: A part remote from the center; outer edge; border; -- usuallyin the plural; as, the outskirts of a town. Wordsworth.The outskirts of his march of mystery. Keble.
OPHIOPHAGUS: A genus of venomous East Indian snakes, which feed on othersnakes. Ophiophagus elaps is said to be the largest and most deadlyof poisonous snakes.
OMOPHAGIC: Eating raw flesh; using uncooked meat as food; as, omophagicfeasts, rites.
OQUASSA: A small, handsome trout (Salvelinus oquassa), found in some ofthe lakes in Maine; -- called also blueback trout.
OUT-HEROD: To surpass (Herod) in violence or wickedness; to exceed in anyvicious or offensive particular. "It out-Herods Herod." Shak.Out-Heroding the preposterous fashions of the times. Sir W. Scott.
OATMEAL: A plant of the genus Panicum; panic grass.
OFFSCOURING: That which is scoured off; hence, refuse; rejected matter; thatwhich is vile or despised. Lam. iii. 45.
ORTHOPTERA: An order of mandibulate insects including grasshoppers,locusts, cockroaches, etc. See Illust. under Insect.
OILNUT: The buffalo nut. See Buffalo nut, under Buffalo.
OPHELIC: Of, pertaining to, or designating, a substance (called ophelicacid) extracted from a plant (Ophelia) of the Gentian family as abitter yellowish sirup, used in India as a febrifuge and tonic.
OVICAPSULE: The outer layer of a Graafian follicle.
OVERMAST: To furnish (a vessel) with too long or too heavy a mast ormasts.
ORGANIZABILITY: Quality of being organizable; capability of being organized.
OSTEOPATHIST: One who practices osteopathy; an osteopath.
OPSIOMETER: An instrument for measuring the limits of distincts vision indifferent individuals, and thus determiming the proper focal lengthof a lens for correcting imperfect sight. Brande & C.
OXTER: The armpit; also, the arm. [Prov. Eng. & Scot.]
OYSTER: Any marine bivalve mollusk of the genus Ostrea. They areusually found adhering to rocks or other fixed objects in shallowwater along the seacoasts, or in brackish water in the mouth ofrivers. The common European oyster (Ostrea edulis), and the Americanoyster (Ostrea Virginiana), are the most important species.
OVERSNOW: To cover with snow, or as with snow. [Poetic] Shak. Dryden.
OSTENTATOR: One fond of display; a boaster. Sherwood.
OSTREA: A genus of bivalve Mollusca which includes the true oysters.
OLIVENITE: An olive-green mineral, a hydrous arseniate of copper; oliveore.
OTALGIC: Of or pertaining to otalgia.-- n.
ORICHALCEOUS: Pertaining to, or resembling, orichalch; having a color orluster like that of brass. Maunder.
ONLOFT: Aloft; above ground. [Obs.]She kept her father's life onloft. Chaucer.
OCTOGYNIA: A Linnaean order of plants having eight pistils.
