OVERSLEEP: To sleep beyond; as, to oversleep one's self or one's usualhour of rising.
ORTHOSCOPIC: Giving an image in correct or normal proportions; giving a flatfield of view; as, an orthoscopic eyepiece.
ORISON: A prayer; a supplication. [Poetic] Chaucer. Shak.Lowly they bowed, adoring, and began Their orisons, each morning dulypaid. Milton.
ORIENCY: Brightness or strength of color. [R.] E. Waterhouse.
OTTO CYCLE: A four-stroke cycle for internal-combustion engines consistingof the following operations: First stroke, suction into cylinder ofexplosive charge, as of gas and air; second stroke, compression,ignition, and explosion of this charge; third stroke (the workingstroke), expansion of the gases; fourth stroke, expulsion of theproducts of combustion from the cylinder. This is the cycle inventedby Beau de Rochas in 1862 and applied by Dr. Otto in 1877 in theOtto-Crossley gas engine, the first commercially successful internal-combustion engine made.
OPTIGRAPH: A telescope with a diagonal eyepiece, suspended vertically ingimbals by the object end beneath a fixed diagonal plane mirror. Itis used for delineating landscapes, by means of a pencil at the eyeend which leaves the delineation on paper.
OPHICLEIDE: A large brass wind instrument, formerly used in the orchestraand in military bands, having a loud tone, deep pitch, and a compassof three octaves; -- now generally supplanted by bass and contrabasstubas. Moore (Encyc. of Music).
OSCININE: Of or pertaining to the Oscines.
OUTFROWN: To frown down; to overbear by frowning. Shak.
OLECRANON: The large process at the proximal end of the ulna whichprojects behind the articulation with the humerus and forms the bonyprominence of the elbow.
OUTSIT: To remain sitting, or in session, longer than, or beyond thetime of; to outstay.
OVERHAND: The upper hand; advantage; superiority; mastery.He had gotten thereby a great overhand on me. Sir T. More.
OBLIGATORILY: In an obligatory manner; by reason of obligation. Foxe.
OVERWORK: To work too much, or beyond one's strength.
OLEFINE: Olefiant gas, or ethylene; hence, by extension, any one of theseries of unsaturated hydrocarbons of which ethylene is a type. SeeEthylene.
OBLIGEMENT: Obligation. [R.]I will not resist, therefore, whatever it is, either of divine orhuman obligement, that you lay upon me. Milton.
OBTURATION: The act of stopping up, or closing, an opening. "Deaf by anoutward obturation." Bp. Hall.
OAFISH: Like an oaf; simple.-- Oaf"ish*ness, n.
OUTSENTRY: A sentry who guards the entrance or approach to a place; anoutguard.
ORTHOSTADE: A chiton, or loose, ungirded tunic, falling in straight folds.
OVERBULK: To oppress by bulk; to overtower. [Obs. & R.] Shak.
OVERAWE: To awe exceedingly; to subjugate or restrain by awe or greatfear.The king was present in person to overlook the magistrates, andoverawe these subjects with the terror of his sword. Spenser.
OMOSTEGITE: The part of the carapace of a crustacean situated behind thecervical groove.
OSCILLOGRAM: An autographic record made by an oscillograph.
OCTOPEDE: An animal having eight feet, as a spider.
OVARIOUS: Consisting of eggs; as, ovarious food. [R.] Thomson.
OPELET: A bright-colored European actinian (Anemonia, or Anthea,sulcata); -- so called because it does not retract its tentacles.
OVERHEAT: To heat to excess; to superheat. Cowper.
OOZY: Miry; containing soft mud; resembling ooze; as, the oozy bed ofa river. Pope.
OPTICS: That branch of physical science which treats of the nature andproperties of light, the laws of its modification by opaque andtransparent bodies, and the phenomena of vision.
OVERDYE: To dye with excess of color; to put one color over (another).Shak.
OVERCROW: To crow, exult, or boast, over; to overpower. Spenser. Shak.
OPTATIVE: Expressing desire or wish. Fuller. Optative mood (Gram.), thatmood or form of a verb, as in Greek, Sanskrit, etc., in which a wishor desire is expressed.
ORTHOGRAPHER: One versed in orthography; one who spells words correctly.
OBSTETRICS: The science of midwifery; the art of assisting women inparturition, or in the trouble incident to childbirth.
OVERWET: Excessive wetness. [Obs.]Another ill accident is, overwet at sowing time. Bacon.
ODONTOCETE: A subdivision of Cetacea, including the sperm whale, dolphins,etc.; the toothed whales.
OUTPARAMOUR: To exceed in the number of mistresses. [R.] Shak.
OSTEOPERIOSTITIS: Inflammation of a bone and its periosteum.
OBSTRUCTIVE: Tending to obstruct; presenting obstacles; hindering; causingimpediment.-- Ob*struct"ive*ly, adv.
OCTAGON: A plane figure of eight sides and eight angles.
OXYSULPHIDE: A ternary compound of oxygen and sulphur.
OSSE: A prophetic or ominous utterance. [R. & Obs.] Holland.
OPHITE: Of or pertaining to a serpent. [Obs.]
OVERANXIOUS: Anxious in an excessive or needless degree.-- O"ver*anx"ious*ly, adv.
OPEN: Open or unobstructed space; clear land, without trees orobstructions; open ocean; open water. "To sail into the open." Jowett(Thucyd. ).Then we got into the open. W. Black.In open, in full view; without concealment; openly. [Obs.] Beau. &Fl.
OXBOW: A frame of wood, bent into the shape of the letter U, andembracing an ox's neck as a kind of collar, the upper ends passingthrough the bar of the yoke; also, anything so shaped, as a bend in ariver.
OUTTAKEN: or prep. Excepted; save. [Obs.] Wyclif. Chaucer.
ON DIT: They say, or it is said.-- n.
ODONTOTORMAE: An order of extinct toothed birds having the teeth in sockets,as in the genus Ichthyornis. See Ichthyornis.
OUTGROWTH: That which grows out of, or proceeds from, anything; anexcrescence; an offshoot; hence, a result or consequence.
OMNIUM-GATHERUM: A miscellaneous collection of things or persons; a confusedmixture; a medley. [Colloq. & Humorous] Selden.
OINTMENT: That which serves to anoint; any soft unctuous substance usedfor smearing or anointing; an unguent.
OSTEODENTINE: A hard substance, somewhat like bone, which is sometimesdeposited within the pulp cavity of teeth.
ORTHOMORPHIC: Having the right form. Orthomorphic projection, a projection inwhich the angles in the figure to be projected are equal to thecorresponding angles in the projected figure.
OSMIC: Pertaining to, derived from, or containing, osmium;specifically, designating those compounds in which it has a valencehigher than in other lower compounds; as, osmic oxide. Osmic acid.(Chem.) (a) Osmic tetroxide. [Obs.] (b) Osmic acid proper, an acidanalogous to sulphuric acid, not known in the free state, but forminga well-known and stable series of salts (osmates), which wereformerly improperly called osmites.-- Osmic tetroxide (Chem.), a white volatile crystalline substance,OsO4, the most stable and characteristic of the compounds of osmium.It has a burning taste, and gives off a vapor, which is a powerfulirritant poison, violently attacking the eyes, and emitting a strongchlorinelike odor. Formerly improperly called osmic acid.
OUTBOARD: Beyond or outside of the lines of a vessel's bulwarks or hull;in a direction from the hull or from the keel; -- opposed to inboard;as, outboard rigging; swing the davits outboard.
OLPE: Originally, a leather flask or vessel for oils or liquids;afterward, an earthenware vase or pitcher without a spout.
ORIENTNESS: The quality or state of being orient or bright; splendor.[Obs.] Fuller.
ORCHID: Any plant of the order Orchidaceæ. See Orchidaceous.
OBJICIENT: One who makes objection; an objector. [R.] Cardinal Wiseman.
OLEACEOUS: Of, pertaining to, or resembling, a natural order of plants(Oleaceæ), mostly trees and shrubs, of which the olive is the type.It includes also the ash, the lilac, the true jasmine, and fringetree.
OMINATE: To presage; to foreshow; to foretoken. [Obs.] Dr. H. More.
ORDERLESS: Being without order or regularity; disorderly; out of rule.
OSTMEN: East men; Danish settlers in Ireland, formerly so called.Lyttelton.
OUTLIMB: , An extreme member or part of a thing; a limb. [Obs.] Fuller.
ORIGINALITY: The quality or state of being original. Macaulay.
OVERPASS: To pass over, away, or off.
OTTO ENGINE: An engine using the Otto cycle.
ORPHIC: Pertaining to Orpheus; Orphean; as, Orphic hymns.
ORTHODROMICS: The art of sailing in a direct course, or on the arc of a greatcircle, which is the shortest distance between any two points on thesurface of the globe; great-circle sailing; orthodromy.
ORGANZINE: A kind of double thrown silk of very fine texture, that is,silk twisted like a rope with different strands, so as to increaseits strength.
OUTREASON: To excel or surpass in reasoning; to reason better than. South.
OFFENSEFUL: Causing offense; displeasing; wrong; as, an offenseful act.[R.]
OBDURATION: A hardening of the heart; hardness of heart. [Obs.]
OCELOT: An American feline carnivore (Felis pardalis). It ranges fromthe Southwestern United States to Patagonia. It is covered withblackish ocellated spots and blotches, which are variously arranged.The ground color varies from reddish gray to tawny yellow.
ORTHOSILICIC: Designating the form of silicic acid having the normal orhighest number of hydroxyl groups.
OLEA: A genus of trees including the olive.
OBSIGNATION: The act of sealing or ratifying; the state of being sealed orconfirmed; confirmation, as by the Holy Spirit.The spirit of manifestation will but upbraid you in the shame andhorror of a sad eternity, if you have not the spirit of obsignation.Jer. Taylor.
OPTOMETER: An instrument for measuring the distance of distinct vision,mainly for the selection of eveglasses.
OFF: In a general sense, denoting from or away from; as:
ODOMETRY: Measurement of distances by the odometer.
OBSECRATE: To beseech; to supplicate; to implore. [R.]. Cockerman.
OLIGOCENE: Of, pertaining to, or designating, certain strata which occupyan intermediate position between the Eocene and Miocene periods.-- n.
OUTSTRIKE: To strike out; to strike faster than. Shak.
OVIPOSIT: To lay or deposit eggs; -- said esp. of insects.
ON: The general signification of on is situation, motion, orcondition with respect to contact or support beneath; as: --
OSTEOLOGIST: One who is skilled in osteology; an osteologer.
OVERTRADE: To trade beyond one's capital; to buy goods beyond the means ofpaying for or seleng them; to overstock the market.
OVOID: A solid resembling an egg in shape.
ORGEAT: A sirup in which, formerly, a decoction of barley entered, butwhich is now prepared with an emulsion of almonds, -- used to flavorbeverages or edibles.
OLEOGRAPH: The form or figure assumed by a drop of oil when placed uponwater or some other liquid with which it does not mix.
ODORINE: A pungent oily substance obtained by redistilling bone oil.[Obs.]
ONENESS: The state of being one; singleness in number; individuality;unity.Our God is one, or rather very oneness. Hooker.
ORGANOLEPTIC: Making an impression upon an organ; plastic; -- said of theeffect or impression produced by any substance on the organs oftouch, taste, or smell, and also on the organism as a whole.
OTTAWAS: A tribe of Indians who, when first known, lived on the OttawaRiver. Most of them subsequently migrated to the southwestern shoreof Lake Superior.
OPEROSE: Wrought with labor; requiring labor; hence, tedious; wearisome."Operose proceeding." Burke. "A very operose calculation." DeQuincey.-- Op"er*ose`ly, adv.-- Op"er*ose`ness, n.
OILED: Covered or treated with oil; dressed with, or soaked in, oil.Oiled silk, silk rendered waterproof by saturation with boiled oil.
OBLATRATION: The act of oblatrating; a barking or snarling. Bp. Hall.
OLIGO-: A combining form from Gr. few, little, small.
OUTMARCH: To surpass in marching; to march faster than, or so as to leavebehind.
OSCILLATIVE: Tending to oscillate; vibratory. [R.] I. Taylor.
OPETIDE: Open time; -- applied to different things:(a) The early spring, or the time when flowers begin opening.[Archaic] Nares.(b) The time between Epiphany and Ash Wednesday wherein marriageswere formerly solemnized publicly in churches. [Eng.](c) The time after harvest when the common fields are open to allkinds of stock. [Prov.Eng.] Halliwell. [Written also opentide.]
OLD-MAIDISM: The condition or characteristics of an old maid. G. Eliot.
OPHTHALMIC: Of, pertaining to, or in the region of, the eye; ocular; as theophthalmic, or orbitonasal, nerve, a division of the trigeminal,which gives branches to the lachrymal gland, eyelids, nose, andforehead. Ophthalmic region (Zoöl.), the space around the eyes.
OVERBURDEN: To load with too great weight or too much care, etc. Sir P.Sidney.
ORTHOEPY: The art of uttering words corectly; a correct pronunciation ofwords; also, mode of pronunciation.
ORTHOCARBONIC: Designating a complex ether, C.(OC2H5)4, which is obtained as aliquid of a pleasant ethereal odor by means of chlorpicrin, and isbelieved to be a derivative of the hypothetical normal carbonic acid,C.(OH)4.
ORANGEADE: A drink made of orange juice and water, corresponding tolemonade; orange sherbet.
OVERLYING: Lying over or upon something; as, overlying rocks.
OBJECTIFY: To cause to become an object; to cause to assume the characterof an object; to render objective. J. D. Morell.
OUTPASS: To pass beyond; to exceed in progress.
OBSIDIAN: A kind of glass produced by volcanoes. It is usually of a blackcolor, and opaque, except in thin splinters.
ORTHOPINACOID: A name given to the two planes in the monoclinic system whichare parallel to the vertical and orthodiagonal axes.
OVOTESTTIS: An organ which produces both ova and spermatozoids; anhermaphrodite gland.
OMNI-: A combining form denoting all, every, everywhere; as inomnipotent, all-powerful; omnipresent.
OMNIBUS: A sheet-iron cover for articles in a leer or annealing arch, toprotect them from drafts. Omnibus bill, a legislative bill whichprovides for a number of miscellaneous enactments or appropriations.[Parliamentary Cant, U.S.] -- Omnibus box, a large box in a theater,on a level with the stage and having communication with it. [Eng.]Thackeray.
ORATRESS: A woman who makes public addresses. Warner.
OXAMIC: Pertaining to, or designating, an acid NH2.C2O2.HO obtained asa fine crystalline powder, intermediate between oxalic acid andoxamide. Its ammonium salt is obtained by boiling oxamide withammonia.
OVERSORROW: To grieve or afflict to excess. [Obs.] Milton.
OVERNICE: Excessively nice; fastidious. Bp. Hall.-- O"ver*nice"ly, adv.-- O"ver*nice"ness, n.
OKRA: An annual plant (Abelmoschus, or Hibiscus, esculentus), whosegreen pods, abounding in nutritious mucilage, are much used forsoups, stews, or pickles; gumbo. [Written also ocra and ochra.]
OVERPAMPER: To pamper excessively; to feed or dress too much. Dryton.
OPPOSITIONIST: One who belongs to the opposition party. Praed.
OSTEOCOPE: Pain in the bones; a violent fixed pain in any part of a bone.-- Os`te*o*cop"ic, a.
OXANILIC: Pertaining to, or derived from, oxalic acid and aniline; --used to designate an acid obtained in white crystalline scales byheating these substances together.
OVER-ARM: Done (as bowling or pitching) with the arm raised above theshoulder. See Overhard. "An over-arm with a round-arm bowler." R. A.Proctor.
OVERQUIETNESS: Too much quietness. Sir. T. Browne.
OUTKEEPER: An attachment to a surveyor's compass for keeping tally inchaining.
OPPRESSOR: One who oppresses; one who imposes unjust burdens on others;one who harasses others with unjust laws or unreasonable severity.The orphan pines while the oppressor feeds. Shak.To relieve the oppressed and to punish the oppressor. Swift.
OCARINA: A kind of small simple wind instrument.
OVERFREE: Free to excess; too liberal; too familiar.-- O"ver*free"ly, adv.
OLIGARCHY: A form of government in which the supreme power is placed inthe hands of a few persons; also, those who form the ruling few.All oligarchies, wherein a few men domineer, do what they list.Burton.
OSCILLATOR: Any device for producing electric oscillations; esp., anapparatus for generating electric waves in a system of wirelesstelegraphy.(b) (Mech.) An instrument for measuring rigidity by the torsionaloscillations of a weighted wire.
OUTLIVE: To live beyond, or longer than; to survive.They live too long who happiness outlive. Dryden.
OUTSTARE: To excel or overcome in staring; to face down.I would outstare the sternest eyes that look. Shak.
OBSCURER: One who, or that which, obscures.
OUTPRIZE: To prize beyong value, or in excess; to exceed in value. [Obs.]Shak.
ORTHOPRAXY: The treatment of deformities in the human body by mechanicalappliances.
OVERFALL: A turbulent surface of water, caused by strong currents settingover submerged ridges; also, a dangerous submerged ridge or shoal.
OUTFLANK: To go beyond, or be superior to, on the flank; to pass aroundor turn the flank or flanks of.
OVERWEENER: One who overweens. [R.]The conceits of warmed or overweening brain. Locke.
OSTEOLYSIS: Softening and absorption of bone. -- Os`te*o*lyt"ic (#), a.
ORDINARY: One who has immediate jurisdiction in matters ecclesiastical;an ecclesiastical judge; also, a deputy of the bishop, or a clergymanappointed to perform divine service for condemned criminals andassist in preparing them for death.(c) (Am. Law) A judicial officer, having generally the powers of ajudge of probate or a surrogate.
OCCISION: A killing; the act of killing. [Obs.] Sir M. Hale.
ORGANO-: A combining form denoting relation to, or connection with, anorgan or organs.
OVARIOTOMY: The operation of removing one or both of the ovaries;oöphorectomy.
OCTAHEDRAL: Having eight faces or sides; of, pertaining to, or formed in,octahedrons; as, octahedral cleavage. Octahedral borax (Chem.), boraxobtained from a saturated solution in octahedral crystals, whichcontain five molecules of water of crystallization; distinguishedfrom common or prismatic borax.-- Octahedral iron ore (Min.), magnetite.
OBCOMPRESSED: Compressed or flattened antero-posteriorly, or in a wayopposite to the usual one.
OBVERSION: The act of immediate inference, by which we deny the oppositeof anything which has been affirmed; as, all men are mortal; then, byobversion, no men are immortal. This is also described as "immediateinference by privative conception." Bain.
ORTHOSCOPE: An instrument designed to show the condition of the superficialportions of the eye.
OENOLOGY: Knowledge of wine, scientific or practical.
OUTJET: That which jets out or projects from anything. [R.] H. Miller.
OCTOROON: The offspring of a quadroon and a white person; a mestee.
OWLERY: An abode or a haunt of owls.
ORIGENISM: The opinions of Origen of Alexandria, who lived in the 3dcentury, one of the most learned of the Greek Fathers. Prominent inhis teaching was the doctrine that all created beings, includingSatan, will ultimately be saved.
OSSELET: The internal bone, or shell, of a cuttlefish.
OUTFIT: A fitting out, or equipment, as of a ship for a voyage, or of aperson for an expedition in an unoccupied region or residence in aforeign land; things required for equipment; the expense of, orallowance made for, equipment, as by the government of the UnitedStates to a diplomatic agent going abroad.
OSSIFYING: Changing into bone; becoming bone; as, the ossifying process.
OCTANDRIA: A Linnæan class of plants, in which the flowers have eightstamens not united to one another or to the pistil.
OEIL-DE-BOEUF: A circular or oval window; -- generally used of architecture ofthe 17th and 18th centuries. A famous room in the palace ofVersailles bears this name, from the oval window opening into it.
OSTEOPHONE: An instrument for transmission of auditory vibrations throughthe bones of the head, so as to be appreciated as sounds by personsdeaf from causes other than those affecting the nervous apparatus ofhearing.
OBTURATE: To stop or close, as an opening; specif., (Ordnance),
ORC: The grampus. [Written also ork and orch.] Milton.
OVERCAST: To take long, loose stitches over (the raw edges of a seam) toprevent raveling.
ORGANOGENESIS: The origin and development of organs in animals and plants.
OENANTHYLATE: A salt of oenanthylic acid; as, potassium oenanthylate.
ORDINATOR: One who ordains or establishes; a director. [R.] T. Adams.
OMASUM: The third division of the stomach of ruminants. See Manyplies,and Illust. under Ruminant.
ORDER: The disposition of a column and its component parts, and of theentablature resting upon it, in classical architecture; hence (as thecolumn and entablature are the characteristic features of classicalarchitecture) a style or manner of architectural designing.
OBNUBILATE: To cloud; to obscure. [Obs.] Burton.-- Ob*nu"bi*la"tion, n. [Obs.] Beddoes.
OYEZ: Hear; attend; -- a term used by criers of courts to securesilence before making a proclamation. It is repeated three times.[Written also oyes.]
OPPOSITION: The situation of a heavenly body with respect to another whenin the part of the heavens directly opposite to it; especially, theposition of a planet or satellite when its longitude differs fromthat of the sun 180º; -- signified by the symbol as, .
OLIVINE: A common name of the yellowish green mineral chrysolite, esp.the variety found in eruptive rocks.
OVERPROUD: Exceedingly or unduly proud. "Overproud of his victory."Milton.
OESTRUS: A genus of gadflies. The species which deposits its larvæ inthe nasal cavities of sheep is oestrus ovis.
OCTAMETER: A verse containing eight feet; as, --Deep'' in|to'' the | dark''ness | peer''ing, | long'' I | stood''there | wond'''ring, | fear''ing. Poe.
OCTAVO: A book composed of sheets each of which is folded into eightleaves; hence, indicating more or less definitely a size of book somade; -- usually written 8vo or 8º.
OROHELIOGRAPH: A camera for obtaining a circular panoramic view of thehorizon. The photographic plate is placed horizontally with avertical lens above. A mirror of peculiar shape reflects light fromthe entire horizon to the lens, by means of which it is focused uponthe plate.
ONOMATOPE: An imitative word; an onomatopoetic word.
OMNISPECTIVE: Beholding everything; capable of seeing all things; all-seeing.[R.] "Omnispective Power!" Boyse.
OXYTOLUENE: One of three hydroxy derivatives of toluene, called thecresols. See Cresol.
ONCOST: In cost accounting, expenditure which is involved in theprocess of manufacture or the performance of work and which cannot becharged directly to any particular article manufactured or work done(as where different kinds of goods are produced), but must beallocated so that each kind of goods or work shall bear its propershare. [Brit.]
ORICHALCH: A metallic substance, resembling gold in color, but inferior invalue; a mixed metal of the ancients, resembling brass; -- calledalso aurichalcum, orichalcum, etc.
ODOMETER: An instrument attached to the wheel of a vehicle, to measurethe distance traversed; also, a wheel used by surveyors, whichregisters the miles and rods traversed.
OBJECTIVITY: The state, quality, or relation of being objective; characterof the object or of the objective.The calm, the cheerfulness, the disinterested objectivity havedisappeared [in the life of the Greeks]. M. Arnold.
OZOCERITE: A waxlike mineral resin; -- sometimes called native paraffin,and mineral wax.
ORGANIST: One who plays on the organ.
OLEIN: A fat, liquid at ordinary temperatures, but solidifying attemperatures below 0° C., found abundantly in both the animal andvegetable kingdoms (see Palmitin). It dissolves solid fats,especially at 30-40° C. Chemically, olein is a glyceride of oleicacid; and, as three molecules of the acid are united to one moleculeof glyceryl to form the fat, it is technically known as triolein. Itis also called elain.
ORTHOTOMOUS: Having two cleavages at right angles with one another.
ORSELLINIC: Pertaining to, or designating, an organic acid obtained by apartial decomposition of orsellic acid as a white crystallinesubstance, and related to protocatechuic acid.
OBFUSCATION: The act of darkening or bewildering; the state of beingdarkened. "Obfuscation of the cornea." E. Darwin.
OUTGROUND: Ground situated at a distance from the house; outlying land.
OCTYLIC: Pertaining to, derived from, or containing, octyl; as, octylicether.
OSWEGO TEA: An American aromatic herb (Monarda didyma), with showy, brightred, labiate flowers.
OSCULATE: To touch closely, so as to have a common curvature at the pointof contact. See Osculation, 2.
OCCIPITAL: Of or pertaining to the occiput, or back part of the head, orto the occipital bone. Occipital bone (Anat.), the bone which formsthe posterior segment of the skull and surrounds the great foramen bywhich the spinal cord leaves the cranium. In the higher vertebratesit is usually composed of four bones, which become consolidated inthe adult.-- Occipital point (Anat.), the point of the occiput in the mesialplane farthest from the ophryon.
OVERSTRAIN: To strain one's self to excess. Dryden.
OUTWRITE: To exceed or excel in writing.
OSCULATRIX: A curve whose contact with a given curve, at a given point, isof a higher order (or involves the equality of a greater number ofsuccessive differential coefficients of the ordinates of the curvestaken at that point) than that of any other curve of the same kind.
OVERHANDLE: To handle, or use, too much; to mention too often. Shak.
OVERSHOOT: To fly beyond the mark. Collier.
ORIGENIST: A follower of Origen of Alexandria.
OUTDO: To go beyond in performance; to excel; to surpass.An imposture outdoes the original. L' Estrange.I grieve to be outdone by Gay. Swift.
OBJECTIONABLE: Liable to objection; likely to be objected to or disapprovedof; offensive; as, objectionable words.-- Ob*jec"tion*a*bly, adv.
OUTWAY: A way out; exit. [R.]In divers streets and outways multiplied. P. Fletcher.
OPHTHALMOSCOPE: An instrument for viewing the interior of the eye, particularlythe retina. Light is thrown into the eye by a mirror (usuallyconcave) and the interior is then examined with or without the aid ofa lens.-- Oph*thal`mo*scop"ic, a.
OVERT: Not covert; open; public; manifest; as, an overt act oftreason. Macaulay.No person shall be convicted of treason unless on the testimony oftwo witnesses to the same overt act, or on confession in open court.Constitution of the U. S.
OCTOGILD: A pecuniary compensation for an injury, of eight times thevalue of the thing.
OUT-OF-DOOR: Being out of the house; being, or done, in the open air;outdoor; as, out-of-door exercise. See Out of door, under Out, adv.Amongst out-of-door delights. G. Eliot.
OBSCURE: To render obscure; to darken; to make dim; to keep in the dark;to hide; to make less visible, intelligible, legible, glorious,beautiful, or illustrious.They are all couched in a pit hard by Herne's oak, with obscuredlights. Shak.Why, 't is an office of discovery, love, And I should be obscured.Shak.There is scarce any duty which has been so obscured by the writingsof learned men as this. Wake.And seest not sin obscures thy godlike frame Dryden.
OXYTONE: Having an acute sound; (Gr. Gram.), having an acute accent onthe last syllable.
OESTRUATION: The state of being under oestrual influence, or of havingsexual desire.
OSCINIAN: One of the Oscines, or singing birds.
OPERATOR: One who performs some act upon the human body by means of thehand, or with instruments.
OUGHTNESS: The state of being as a thing ought to be; rightness. [R.] N.W. Taylor.
OMNIPARITY: Equality in every part; general equality.
OTOCRANIAL: Of or pertaining to the otocrane.
OVERMEDDLING: Excessive interference. "Justly shent for their overmeddling."Fuller.
OUTRING: To excel in volume of ringing sound; to ring louder than.
OBESITY: The state or quality of being obese; incumbrance of flesh.
OUTMANTLE: To excel in mantling; hence, to excel in splendor, as of dress.[R.]And with poetic trappings grace thy prose, Till it outmantle all thepride of verse. Cowper.
OVERCLOUD: To cover or overspread with clouds; to becloud; to overcast.
OVOVIVIPAROUS: Oviparous, but hatching the egg while it is within the body, assome fishes and reptiles.
ORPHEUS: The famous mythic Thracian poet, son of the Muse Calliope, andhusband of Eurydice. He is reputed to have had power to entrancebeasts and inanimate objects by the music of his lyre.
OXYMURIATIC: Pertaining to, or consisting of, oxygen and muriatic acid, thatis, hydrochloric acid. [Archaic.] Oxymuriatic acid, chlorine,formerly so called on the supposition that it was a compound ofoxygen and muriatic acid. [Obs.]
OBTESTATION: The act of obtesting; supplication; protestation. [R.]Antonio asserted this with great obtestation. Evelyn.
OBSERVING: Giving particular attention; habitually attentive to whatpasses; as, an observing person; an observing mind.-- Ob*serv"ing*ly, adv.
OSSIANIC: Of or pertaining to, or characteristic of, Ossian, a legendaryErse or Celtic bard.The compositions might be fairly classed as Ossianic. G. Eliot.
OSCULATORY: Pertaining to, or having the properties of, an osculatrix;capable of osculation; as, a circle may be osculatory with a curve,at a given point. Osculatory circle. (Geom.) See Osculating circle ofa curve, under Circle.-- Osculatory plane (to a curve of double curvature), a plane whichpasses through three successive points of the curve.-- Osculatory sphere (to a line of double curvature), a spherepassing through four consecutive points of the curve.
OVERSOW: To sow where something has already been sown. [R.]His enemy came and oversowed cockle among the wheat. Matt. x
ORANGEISM: Attachment to the principles of the society of Orangemen; thetenets or practices of the Orangemen.
OPINABLE: Capable of being opined or thought. Holland.
OCTET: A composition for eight parts, usually for eight soloinstruments or voices.
OUTSTANDING: That stands out; undischarged; uncollected; not paid; as,outstanding obligations.Revenues . . . as well outstanding as collected. A. Hamilton.
ORBITARY: Situated around the orbit; as, the orbitary feathers of a bird.
OVATE-OBLONG: Oblong. with one end narrower than the other; ovato-oblong.
OUREBI: A small, graceful, and swift African antelope, allied to theklipspringer.
OUTBOWED: Convex; curved outward. "The convex or outbowed side of avessel." Bp. Hall.
OTOLOGY: The branch of science which treats of the ear and its diseases.
ORDONNANCE: The disposition of the parts of any composition with regard toone another and the whole.Their dramatic ordonnance of the parts. Coleridge.
OVERJUMP: To jump over; hence, to omit; to ignore. Marston.
OENANTHATE: A salt of the supposed oenanthic acid.
OLD DOMINION: Virginia; -- a name of uncertain origin, perh. from the olddesignation of the colony as "the Colony and Dominion of Virginia."
OSTEOLOGER: One versed in osteology; an osteologist.
OBLIGOR: The person who binds himself, or gives his bond to another.Blackstone.
OCHLOCRACY: A form of government by the multitude; a mobocracy. Hare.
OSTENTATIOUS: Fond of, or evincing, ostentation; unduly conspicuous;pretentious; boastful.Far from being ostentatious of the good you do. Dryden.The ostentatious professions of many years. Macaulay.-- Os`ten*ta"tious*ly, adv.-- Os`ten*ta"tious*ness, n.
ODALISQUE: A female slave or concubine in the harem of the Turkish sultan.[Written also odahlic, odalisk, and odalik.]Not of those that men desire, sleek Odalisques, or oracles of mode.Tennyson.
OPEN SEA: A sea open to all nations. See Mare clausum.
ORBICLE: A small orb, or sphere. [Obs.] G. Fletcher.
OD: An alleged force or natural power, supposed, by Reichenbach andothers, to produce the phenomena of mesmerism, and to be developed byvarious agencies, as by magnets, heat, light, chemical or vitalaction, etc.; -- called also odyle or the odylic force. [Archaic]That od force of German Reichenbach Which still, from female fingertips, burnt blue. Mrs. Browning.
OXIME: One of a series of isonitroso derivatives obtained by theaction of hydroxylamine on aldehydes or ketones.
ODEON: A kind of theater in ancient Greece, smaller than the dramatictheater and roofed over, in which poets and musicians submitted theirworks to the approval of the public, and contended for prizes; --hence, in modern usage, the name of a hall for musical or dramaticperformances.
OURSELVES: ; sing. Ourself (we; also, alone in the predicate, in thenominative or the objective case.We ourselves might distinctly number in words a great deal furtherthen we usually do. Locke.Safe in ourselves, while on ourselves we stand. Dryden.
OFTENSITH: Frequently; often. [Obs.]For whom I sighed have so oftensith. Gascoigne.
OVERSOUL: The all-containing soul. [R.]That unity, that oversout, within which every man's particular beingis contained and made one with all other. Emerson.
OBSCENITY: That quality in words or things which presents what isoffensive to chasity or purity of mind; obscene or impure lanquage oracts; moral impurity; lewdness; obsceneness; as, the obscenity of aspeech, or a picture.Mr.Cowley asserts plainly, that obscenity has no place in wit.Dryden.No pardon vile obscenity should find. Pope.
OVERCARRY: To carry too far; to carry beyond the proper point. Hayward.
OPTIME: One of those who stand in the second rank of honors,immediately after the wranglers, in the University of Cambridge,England. They are divided into senior and junior optimes.
OMPHALOTOMY: The operation of dividing the navel-string.
OMNIVOROUS: All-devouring; eating everything indiscriminately; as,omnivorous vanity; esp. (Zoöl.), eating both animal and vegetablefood.-- Om*niv"o*rous*ness, n.
OSIERED: Covered or adorned with osiers; as, osiered banks. [Poetic]Collins.
OVERBOIL: To boil over or unduly.Nor is discontent to keep the mind Deep in its fountain, lest itoverboil In the hot throng. Byron.
ORTHOCLASTIC: Breaking in directions at right angles to each other; -- saidof the monoclinic feldspars.
OVERPRESSURE: Excessive pressure or urging. London Athenæum.
OBSCUREMENT: The act of obscuring, or the state of being obscured;obscuration. Pomfret.
OLAY: Palm leaves, prepared for being written upon with a stylepointed with steel. [Written also ola.] Balfour (Cyc. of India).
ORTHOGRAPHIST: One who spells words correctly; an orthographer.
ODD FELLOW: A member of a secret order, or fraternity, styled theIndependent Order of Odd Fellows, established for mutual aid andsocial enjoyment.
OPERATE: To perform some manual act upon a human body in a methodicalmanner, and usually with instruments, with a view to restoresoundness or health, as in amputation, lithotomy, etc.
OEDEMA: A swelling from effusion of watery fluid in the cellular tissuebeneath the skin or mucous membrance; dropsy of the subcutaneouscellular tissue. [Written also edema.]
OUTDATED: Being out of date; antiquated. [Obs.] Hammond.
OBSTRUENT: Causing obstruction; blocking up; hindering; as, an obstruentmedicine. Johnson.
OSTREACEOUS: Of or pertaining to an oyster, or to a shell; shelly.The crustaceous or ostreaceous body. Cudworth.
OBSTETRICATE: To perform the office of midwife. [Obs.] "Nature doesobstetricate." Evelyn.
OVERSTAY: To stay beyond the time or the limits of; as, to overstay theappointed time. Bp. Hall.
OBDUCT: To draw over; to cover. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
OOZE LEATHER: Leather made from sheep and calf skins by mechanically forcingooze through them; esp., such leather with a soft, finely granulatedfinish (called sometimes velvet finish) put on the flesh side forspecial purposes. Ordinary ooze leather is used for shoe uppers, inbookbinding, etc. Hence Ooze calf, Ooze finish, etc.
OSCILLANCY: The state of oscillating; a seesaw kind of motion. [R.]
OBLANCEOLATE: Lanceolate in the reversed order, that is, narrowing toward thepoint of attachment more than toward the apex.
OXYCRATE: A Mixture of water and vinegar. Wiseman.
OUTRECKON: To exceed in reckoning or computation. Bp. Pearson.
OPISOMETER: An instrument with a revolving wheel for measuring a curvedline, as on a map.
ODIBLE: Fitted to excite hatred; hateful. [Obs.] Bale.
OVATE-ACUMINATE: Having an ovate form, but narrowed at the end into a slenderpoint.
OIL: Any one of a great variety of unctuous combustible substances,not miscible with water; as, olive oil, whale oil, rock oil, etc.They are of animal, vegetable, or mineral origin and of variedcomposition, and they are variously used for food, for solvents, foranointing, lubrication, illumination, etc. By extension, anysubstance of an oily consistency; as, oil of vitriol.
OFFERABLE: Capable of being offered; suitable or worthy to be offered.
OBSERVATIONAL: Of a pertaining to observation; consisting of, or containing,observations. Chalmers.
OVARY: That part of the pistil which contains the seed, and in mostflowering plants develops into the fruit. See Illust. of Flower.
OLD-FASHIONED: Formed according to old or obsolete fashion or pattern;adhering to old customs or ideas; as, an old-fashioned dress, girl."Old-fashioned men of wit." Addison.This old-fashioned, quaint abode. Longfellow.
ORBY: Orblike; having the course of an orb; revolving. [Obs.] "Orbyhours." Chapman.
OVERCOME: To gain the superiority; to be victorious. Rev. iii. 21.
OSMOGRAPH: An instrument for recording the height of the liquid in anendosmometer or for registering osmotic pressures.
ONOCERIN: A white crystalline waxy substance extracted from the root ofthe leguminous plant Ononis spinosa.
OUTLYING: Lying or being at a distance from the central part, or the mainbody; being on, or beyond, the frontier; exterior; remote; detached.
OBSIGNATORY: Ratifying; confirming by sealing. [Obs.] Samuel Ward (1643)
OPENER: One who, or that which, opens. "True opener of my eyes."Milton.
OCTYL: A hypothetical hydrocarbon radical regarded as an essentialresidue of octane, and as entering into its derivatives; as, octylalcohol.
OMNISCIENT: Having universal knowledge; knowing all things; infinitelyknowing or wise; as, the omniscient God.-- Om*nis"cient*ly, adv.For what can scape the eye Of God all-seeing, or deceive his heartOmniscient Milton.
OFFERTURE: Offer; proposal; overture. [Obs.]More offertures and advantages to his crown. Milton.
ONESELF: A reflexive form of the indefinite pronoun one. Commonly writenas two words, one's self.One's self (or more properly oneself), is quite a modern form. InElizabethan English we find a man's self=one's self. Morris.
ORGANOPLASTIC: Having the property of producing the tissues or organs ofanimals and plants; as, the organoplastic cells.
OWLET: A small owl; especially, the European species (Athene noctua),and the California flammulated owlet (Megascops flammeolus). Owletmoth (Zoöl.), any noctuid moth.
OBOLO: A copper coin, used in the Ionian Islands, about one cent invalue.
OUTBREATHE: To issue, as breath; to be breathed out; to exhale. Beau. & Fl.
OVERWIND: To wind too tightly, as a spring, or too far, as a hoistingrope on a drum.
OWNERSHIP: The state of being an owner; the right to own; exclusive rightof possession; legal or just claim or title; proprietorship.
OPPONENT: Situated in front; opposite; hence, opposing; adverse;antagonistic. Pope.
OSTRACODERMI: A suborder of fishes of which Ostracion is the type.
OVERCANOPY: To cover as with a canopy. Shak.
OOZE: To cause to ooze. Alex. Smith.
OBLUCTATION: A struggle against; resistance; opposition. [Obs.] Fotherby.
OUTFACE: To face or look (one) out of countenance; to resist or beardown by bold looks or effrontery; to brave. Shak.Having outfaced all the world. South.
OBTRUDE: To thrust one's self upon a company or upon attention; tointrude.
ONYX: Chalcedony in parallel layers of different shades of color. Itis used for making cameos, the figure being cut in one layer with thenext as a ground. Onyx marble, a banded variety of marble or calciumcarbonate resembling onyx. It is obtained from Mexico.
OPHIDIOID: Of or pertaining to the Ophidiidæ, a family of fishes whichincludes many slender species.-- n.
OUCH: A socket or bezel holding a precious stone; hence, a jewel orornament worn on the person.A precious stone in a rich ouche. Sir T. Elyot.Your brooches, pearls, and ouches. Shak.
OUTSTAY: To stay beyond or longer than.She concluded to outstay him. Mad. D' Arblay.
OVOLO: A round, convex molding. See Illust. of Column.
OUTSTRIP: To go faster than; to outrun; to advance beyond; to leavebehing.Appetites which . . . had outstripped the hours. Southey.He still outstript me in the race. Tennyson.
OLIVARY: Like an olive. Olivary body (Anat.), an oval prominence on eachside of the medulla oblongata; -- called also olive.
OTOSCOPEIC: Of or pertaining to the otoscope or to otoscopy.
OSSIFIED: Changed to bone or something resembling bone; hardened bydeposits of mineral matter of any kind; -- said of tissues.
ONEBERRY: The herb Paris. See Herb Paris, under Herb.
OPHIUCHUS: A constellation in the Northern Hemisphere, delineated as a manholding a serpent in his hands; -- called also Serpentarius.
OVERDATE: To date later than the true or proper period. Milton.
ORGANONYMY: The designation or nomenclature of organs. B. G. Wilder.
OVERAFFECT: To affect or care for unduly. [Obs.] Milton.
OBERON: The king of the fairies, and husband of Titania or Queen Mab.Shak.
ORBITELAE: A division of spiders, including those that make geometricalwebs, as the garden spider, or Epeira.
OSCINES: Singing birds; a group of the Passeres, having numeroussyringeal muscles, conferring musical ability.
OASIS: A fertile or green spot in a waste or desert, esp. in a sandydesert.
ORARIAN: Of or pertaining to a coast.
OUTFLY: To surpass in flying; to fly beyond or faster than. Shak.Winged with fear outflies the wind. Waller.
ORSELLIC: Pertaining to, or designating, an acid found in certainlichens, and called also lecanoric acid. [Formerly written alsoorseillic.]
OSTEOBLAST: One of the protoplasmic cells which occur in the osteogeneticlayer of the periosteum, and from or around which the matrix of thebone is developed; an osteoplast.
ORGANICISM: The doctrine of the localization of disease, or which refers italways to a material lesion of an organ. Dunglison.
ORGANICALNESS: The quality or state of being organic.
OPAQUE: That which is opaque; opacity. Young.
OBJECTIZE: To make an object of; to regard as an object; to place in theposition of an object.In the latter, as objectized by the former, arise the emotions andaffections. Coleridge.
OUTRAYE: See Outrage, v. i. [Obs.]This warn I you, that ye not suddenly Out of yourself for no woeshould outraye. Chaucer.
OFFENDER: One who offends; one who violates any law, divine or human; awrongdoer.I and my son Solomon shall be counted offenders. 1 Kings i. 21.
OROIDE: An alloy, chiefly of copper and zinc or tin, resembling gold incolor and brilliancy. [Written also oreide.]
OPHIDION: The typical genus of ophidioid fishes. [Written also Ophidium.]See Illust. under Ophidioid.
OBSESS: To besiege; to beset. Sir T. Elyot.
OROHIPPUS: A genus of American Eocene mammals allied to the horse, buthaving four toes in front and three behind.
ORTHOTOMY: The property of cutting at right angles.
OPIUM: The inspissated juice of the Papaver somniferum, or whitepoppy.
OVERMOST: Over the rest in authority; above all others; highest. [Obs.]Fabyan.
OXYPHENIC: Pertaining to, or designating, the phenol formerly calledoxyphenic acid, and now oxyphenol and pyrocatechin. See Pyrocatechin.
ORPHANOTROPHISM: The care and support of orphans. [R.] Cotton Mather (1711).
OVEREST: Uppermost; outermost.Full threadbare was his overeste courtepy. Chaucer.
ORATRIX: A woman plaintiff, or complainant, in equity pleading. Burrill.
ORTHOGNATHISM: The quality or state of being orthognathous. Huxley.
OZENA: A discharge of fetid matter from the nostril, particularly ifassociated with ulceration of the soft parts and disease of the bonesof the nose.
ORGASM: Eager or immoderate excitement or action; the state ofturgescence of any organ; erethism; esp., the height of venerealexcitement in sexual intercourse.
OXIDE: A binary compound of oxygen with an atom or radical, or acompound which is regarded as binary; as, iron oxide, ethyl oxide,nitrogen oxide, etc.
OVERSCRUPULOUSNESS: The quality or state of being overscrupulous; excess ofscrupulousness.
OPALIZE: To convert into opal, or a substance like opal. Lyell.
ORCHESTRAL: Of or pertaining to an orchestra; suitable for, or performed inor by, an orchestra.
OFFICE: The apartments or outhouses in which the domestics dischargethe duties attached to the service of a house, as kitchens, pantries,stables, etc. [Eng.]As for the offices, let them stand at distance. Bacon.
OVERGAZE: To gaze; to overlook. [Poetic] "Earth's o'ergazing mountains."Byron.
OTOZOUM: An extinct genus of huge vertebrates, probably dinosaurs, knownonly from four-toed tracks in Triassic sandstones.
OUR: Of or pertaining to us; belonging to us; as, our country; ourrights; our troops; our endeavors. See I.The Lord is our defense. Ps. lxxxix. 18.
ODIN: The supreme deity of the Scandinavians; -- the same as Woden,of the German tribes.There in the Temple, carved in wood, The image of great Odin stood.Longfellow.
OGHAM: A particular kind of writing practiced by the ancient Irish,and found in inscriptions on stones, metals, etc. [Written alsoogam.]
OBOLARY: Possessing only small coins; impoverished. [R.] Lamb.
OLITORY: Of or pertaining to, or produced in, a kitchen garden; used forkitchen purposes; as, olitory seeds.At convenient distance towards the olitory garden. Evelyn.
ORISMOLOGY: That departament of natural history which treats of technicalterms.
OUTBLUSH: To exceed in blushing; to surpass in rosy color. T. Shipman.
OVERLORDSHIP: Lordship or supremacy of a person or a people over others. J.R. Green.
OSAGES: A tribe of southern Sioux Indians, now living in the IndianTerritory.
OUTWIND: To extricate by winding; to unloose. [R.] Spenser. Dr. H. More.
OUTRAGE: To rage in excess of. [R.] Young.
OVERFREIGHT: To put too much freight in or upon; to load too full, or tooheavily; to overload.
OUTDWELL: To dwell or stay beyond. [Poetic] "He outdwells his hour."Shak.
ORNITHOSCELIDA: A group of extinct Reptilia, intermediate in structure(especially with regard to the pelvis) between reptiles and birds.-- Or`ni*tho*scel"i*dan, a.
ORDINATELY: In an ordinate manner; orderly. Chaucer. Skelton.
OFFERER: One who offers; esp., one who offers something to God inworship. Hooker.
OMEN: An occurrence supposed to portend, or show the character of,some future event; any indication or action regarded as aforeshowing; a foreboding; a presage; an augury.Bid go with evil omen, and the brand Of infamy upon my name. Milton.
OVERLOGICAL: Excessively logical; adhering too closely to the forms or rulesof logic.
OCTODECIMO: Having eighteen leaves to a sheet; as, an octodecimo form,book, leaf, size, etc.
OXAMIDINE: One of a series of bases containing the amido and theisonitroso groups united to the same carbon atom.
OSTENSION: The showing of the sacrament on the altar in order that it mayreceive the adoration of the communicants.
OVERCAPABLE: Too capable. [R.]Overcapable of such pleasing errors. Hooker.
OUSEL: One of several species of European thrushes, especially theblackbird (Merula merula, or Turdus merula), and the mountain or ringousel (Turdus torquatus). [Written also ouzel.] Rock ousel (Zoöl.),the ring ousel.-- Water ousel (Zoöl.), the European dipper (Cinclus aquaticus), andthe American dipper (C. Mexicanus).
OVERLANGUAGED: Employing too many words; diffuse. Lowell.
OSTRACIONT: A fish of the genus Ostracion and allied genera.
OUTNESS: The state or quality of being distanguishable from theperceiving mind, by being in space, and possessing marerial quality;externality; objectivity.The outness of the objects of sense. Sir W. Hamiltom.
OUTSPORT: To exceed in sporting. [R.] "Not to outsport discretion." Shak.
OVOLOGY: That branch of natural history which treats of the origin andfunctions of eggs.
OUTWARD: External form; exterior. [R.]So fair an outward and such stuff within. Shak.
OVATE-CYLINDRACEOUS: Having a form intermediate between ovate and cylindraceous.
OBVERT: To turn toward.If its base be obverted towards us. I. Watts.
OBITUAL: Of or pertaining to obits, or days when obits are celebrated;as, obitual days. Smart.
OENANTHYLIC: Pertaining to, derived from, or containing, oenanthyl;specifically, designating an acid formerly supposed to be identicalwith the acid in oenanthic ether, but now known to be identical withheptoic acid.
ORRERY: An apparatus which illustrates, by the revolution of ballsmoved by wheelwork, the relative size, periodic motions, positions,orbits, etc., of bodies in the solar system.
OCCURRENT: Occurring or happening; hence, incidental; accidental.
OUTCOURT: An outer or exterior court.The skirts and outcourts of heaven. South.
OCTYLENE: Any one of a series of metameric hydrocarbons (C8H16) of theethylene series. In general they are combustible, colorless liquids.
OVERPESTER: To pester exceedingly or excessively. Sir W. Raleigh.
OVEROFFICE: To domineer over by virtue of office. [Obs.] Shak.
OLEAGINOUS: Having the nature or qualities of oil; oily; unctuous.
OCTATEUCH: A collection of eight books; especially, the first eight booksof the Old Testament. [R.]
OBSERVANTINE: One of a branch of the Order of Franciscans, who profess toadhere more strictly than the Conventuals to the intention of thefounder, especially as to poverty; -- called also Observants.
OVARIOLE: One of the tubes of which the ovaries of most insects arecomposed.
OVERPEER: To peer over; to rise above.
ORGIASTIC: Pertaining to, or of the nature of, orgies. Elton.
OBJURATION: A binding by oath. [R.] Abp. Bramhall.
OVERFULLNESS: The state of being excessively or abnormally full, so as tocause overflow, distention, or congestion; excess of fullness;surfeit.
OVERNAME: To name over or in a series; to recount. [Obs.] Shak.
ORNITHOIDICHNITE: A fossil track resembling that of a bird. Hitchcock.
OVERSTATE: To state in too strong terms; to exaggerate. Fuller.
OVERWISE: Too wise; affectedly wise.-- O`ver*wise"ly, adv.-- O`ver*wise"ness, n.
OENOTHIONIC: Pertaining to an acid now called sulphovinic, or ethylsulphuric, acid.
OCCUPANCY: The act of taking or holding possession; possession;occupation. Title by occupancy (Law), a right of property acquired bytaking the first possession of a thing, or possession of a thingwhich belonged to nobody, and appropriating it. Blackstone. Kent.
OBSEQUIOUSNESS: The quality or state of being obsequious. South.
ORRIS: A plant of the genus Iris (I. Florentina); a kind of flower-de-luce. Its rootstock has an odor resembling that of violets. Orris pea(Med.), an issue pea made from orris root.-- Orris root, the fragrant rootstock of the orris.
ORTHOTROPIC: Having the longer axis vertical; -- said of erect stems. Encyc.Brit.
OXALURIC: Pertaining to, or designating, a complex nitrogenous acidrelated to the ureids, and obtained from parabanic acid as a whitesilky crystalline substance.
ORICALCHE: See Orichalch.Costly oricalche from strange Phoenice. Spenser.
OUTBALANCE: To outweight; to exceed in weight or effect.Let dull Ajax bear away my right When all his days outbalance thisone night. Dryden.
OSTEOTOMY: The operation of dividing a bone or of cutting a piece out ofit, -- done to remedy deformity, etc.
OUARINE: A Brazilian monkey of the genus Mycetes.
OMO-: A combining form used in anatomy to indicate connection with,or relation to, the shoulder or the scapula.
OSSIFICATION: The formation of bone; the process, in the growth of an animal,by which inorganic material (mainly lime salts) is deposited incartilage or membrane, forming bony tissue; ostosis.
OVERMOUNT: To mount over; to go higher than; to rise above.
OCTANGULAR: Having eight angles; eight-angled.-- Oc*tan"gu*lar*ness, n.
OPISTHOGRAPHY: A writing upon the back of anything, as upon the back of a leafor sheet already written upon on one side. [R.] Scudamore.
OPEN VERDICT: A verdict on a preliminary investigation, finding the fact of acrime but not stating the criminal, or finding the fact of a violentdeath without disclosing the cause.
OSTRACISM: Banishment by popular vote, -- a means adopted at Athens to ridthe city of a person whose talent and influence gave umbrage.
OXYBUTYRIC: Hydroxybutyric; designating any one of a group of metamericacids (C3H6.OH.CO2H).
OPITULATION: The act of helping or aiding; help. [Obs.] Bailey.
OCTONAPHTHENE: A colorless liquid hydrocarbon of the octylene series,occurring in Caucasian petroleum.
ORTHO-: A combining form (also used adjectively), designating:(a) (Inorganic Chem.) The one of several acids of the same element(as the phosphoric acids), which actually occurs with the greatestnumber of hydroxyl groups; as, orthophosphoric acid. Cf. Normal. (b)(Organic Chem.)
OVERHOLD: To hold or value too highly; to estimate at too dear a rate.[Obs.] Shak.
OXYCALCIUM: Of or pertaining to oxygen and calcium; as, the oxycalciumlight. See Drummond light.
OPTABLE: That may be chosen; desirable. [Obs.] Cockeram.
OVERWEATHER: To expose too long to the influence of the weather. [Obs.]Shak.
ORBED: Having the form of an orb; round.The orbèd eyelids are let down. Trench.
OCCLUSION: The transient approximation of the edges of a natural opening;imperforation. Dunglison. Occlusion of gases (Chem. & Physics), thephenomenon of absorbing gases, as exhibited by platinum, palladium,iron, or charcoal; thus, palladium absorbs, or occludes, nearly athousand times its own volume of hydrogen, and in this case achemical compound seems to be formed.
OXYGON: A triangle having three acute angles.
OMNIPARIENT: Producing or bringing forth all things; all-producing. [R.]
OUTWIT: To surpass in wisdom, esp. in cunning; to defeat or overreachby superior craft.They did so much outwit and outwealth us ! Gauden.
ORGYIA: A genus of bombycid moths whose caterpillars (esp. those ofOrgyia leucostigma) are often very injurious to fruit trees and shadetrees. The female is wingless. Called also vaporer moth.
OCTAPLA: A portion of the Old Testament prepared by Origen in the 3dcentury, containing the Hebrew text and seven Greek versions of it,arranged in eight parallel columns.
ODONTOPTERYX: An extinct Eocene bird having the jaws strongly serrated, ordentated, but destitute of true teeth. It was found near London.
OUTRAGEOUS: Of the nature of an outrage; exceeding the limits of right,reason, or decency; involving or doing an outrage; furious; violent;atrocious. "Outrageous weeping." Chaucer. "The most outrageousvillainies." Sir P. Sidney. "The vile, outrageous crimes." Shak."Outrageous panegyric." Dryden.
ODIC: Of or pertaining to od. See Od. [Archaic] -- Od"ic*al*ly, adv.
OBTUSE: Having an obtuse angle; as, an obtuse-angled triangle.
OPHIOLOGY: That part of natural history which treats of the ophidians, orserpents.
ORGANOGEN: A name given to any one of the four elements, carbon, hydrogen,oxygen, and nitrogen, which are especially characteristic ingredientsof organic compounds; also, by extension, to other elements sometimesfound in the same connection; as sulphur, phosphorus, etc.
OVERMEASURE: To measure or estimate too largely.
OERSTED: The C.G.S. unit of magnetic reluctance or resistance, equal tothe reluctance of a centimeter cube of air (or vacuum) betweenparallel faces. Also, a reluctance in which unit magnetomotive forcesets up unit flux.
OVERCOAT: A coat worn over the other clothing; a greatcoat; a topcoat.
OVERPLY: To ply to excess; to exert with too much vigor; to overwork.Milton.
OPOPANAX: The inspissated juice of an umbelliferous plant (the OpoponaxChironum), brought from Turkey and the East Indies in loose granules,or sometimes in larger masses, of a reddish yellow color, with specksof white. It has a strong smell and acrid taste, and was formerlyused in medicine as an emmenagogue and antispasmodic. Dunglison.
OBJECTABLE: Such as can be presented in opposition; that may be put forwardas an objection. [R.]
OCCULTATION: The hiding of a heavenly body from sight by the intervention ofsome other of the heavenly bodies; -- applied especially to eclipsesof stars and planets by the moon, and to the eclipses of satellitesof planets by their primaries.
ODYLIC: Of or pertaining to odyle; odic; as, odylic force. [Archaic]
OLD LINE STATE: Maryland; a nickname, alluding to the fact that its northernboundary in Mason and Dixon's line.
OBIISM: Belief in, or the practice of, the obi superstitions and rites.
OUTGOING: Going out; departing; as, the outgoing administration; anoutgoing steamer.
ODORIFEROUS: Bearing or yielding an odor; perfumed; usually, sweet of scent;fragrant; as, odoriferous spices, particles, fumes, breezes. Milton.-- O`dor*if"er*ous*ly, adv. --O`dor*if"er*ous*ness, n.
OFFSHORE: From the shore; as, an offshore wind; an offshore signal.
OPISTHOTIC: The inferior and posterior of the three elements forming theperiotic bone.
OUTDRAW: To draw out; to extract. [R.] "He must the teeth outdraw."Gower.
ONEIROCRITIC: An interpreter of dreams. Bp. Warburton. Addison.
OCCASIONATE: To occasion. [Obs.]The lowest may occasionate much ill. Dr. H. More.
OREADES: A group of butterflies which includes the satyrs. See Satyr, 2.
OPPILATION: The act of filling or crowding together; a stopping byredundant matter; obstruction, particularly in the lower intestines.Jer. Taylor.
OSS: To prophesy; to presage. [R. & Obs.] R. Edgeworth.
OPIATE: Inducing sleep; somniferous; narcotic; hence, anodyne; causingrest, dullness, or inaction; as, the opiate rod of Hermes. Milton.
ODIZE: To charge with od. See Od. [Archaic]
OCTOCERATA: A suborder of Cephalopoda including Octopus, Argonauta, andallied genera, having eight arms around the head; -- called alsoOctopoda.
ODONTOGENY: Generetion, or mode of development, of the teeth.
OUTGUARD: A guard or small body of troops at a distance from the mainbody of an army, to watch for the approach of an enemy; hence,anything for defense placed at a distance from the thing to bedefended.
ORGANLING: A large kind of sea fish; the orgeis.
OUTDREAM: To pass, or escape, while dreaming. "To oultdream dangers."Beau. & Fl.
OMPHALODE: The central part of the hilum of a seed, through which thenutrient vessels pass into the rhaphe or the chalaza; -- called alsoomphalodium.
OPAH: A large oceanic fish (Lampris quttatus), inhabiting theAtlantic Ocean. It is remarkable for its brilliant colors, which arered, green, and blue, with tints of purple and gold, covered withround silvery spots. Called also king of the herrings.
OUTCOMPASS: To exceed the compass or limits of. Bacon.
OBJECTIVENESS: Objectivity.Is there such a motion or objectiveness of external bodies, whichproduceth light Sir M. Hale
ODONTOLCAE: An extinct order of ostrichlike aquatic birds having teeth,which are set in a groove in the jaw. It includes Hesperornis, andallied genera. See Hesperornis. [Written also Odontholcae, andOdontoholcae.]
ORGANIZABLE: Capable of being organized; esp. (Biol.), capable of beingformed into living tissue; as, organizable matter.
OBELISK: A mark of reference; -- called also dagger [&dag;]. See Dagger,n., 2.
ORCHESTIAN: Any species of amphipod crustacean of the genus Orchestia, orfamily Orchestidæ. See Beach flea, under Beach.
OVERSKIP: To skip or leap over; to treat with indifference. Shak.
OCEAN: Of or pertaining to the main or great sea; as, the ocean waves;an ocean stream. Milton.
OXLIP: The great cowslip (Primula veris, var. elatior).
OEDEMATOUS: Pertaining to, or of the nature of, edema; affected with edema.
OMENED: Attended by, or containing, an omen or omens; as, happy-omenedday.
OAST: A kiln to dry hops or malt; a cockle. Mortimer.
OREODONT: Resembling, or allied to, the genus Oreodon.
OUTBOUNDS: The farthest or exterior bounds; extreme limits; boundaries.Spenser.
OUTTELL: To surpass in telling, counting, or reckoning. "I have outtoldthe clock." Beau. & Fl.
OTTER: Any carnivorous animal of the genus Lutra, and related genera.Several species are described. They have large, flattish heads, shortears, and webbed toes. They are aquatic, and feed on fish. Their furis soft and valuable. The common otter of Europe is Lutra vulgaris;the American otter is L. Canadensis; other species inhabit SouthAmerica and Asia.
ORGANIFIC: Making an organic or organized structure; producing anorganism; acting through, or resulting from, organs. Prof. Park.
OPALESCENCE: A reflection of a milky or pearly light from the interior of amineral, as in the moonstone; the state or quality of beingopalescent.
OVERISSUE: An excessive issue; an issue, as of notes or bonds, exceedingthe limit of capital, credit, or authority.An overissue of government paper. Brougham.
OVERSPEAK: To exceed in speaking; to speak too much; to use too manywords.
ORDERLINESS: The state or quality of being orderly.
OFFICINAL: Kept in stock by apothecaries; -- said of such drugs andmedicines as may be obtained without special preparation orcompounding; not magistral.
OXALIS: A genus of plants,mostly herbs, with acid-tasting trifoliolateor multifoliolate leaves; -- called also wood sorrel.
OXYCHLORIDE: A ternary compound of oxygen and chlorine; as, plumbicoxychloride.
OCTOATE: A salt of an octoic acid; a caprylate.
OMICRON: Lit., the little, or short, O, o; the fifteenth letter of theGreek alphabet.
OVERFULL: Too full; filled to overflowing; excessively full; surfeited.Shak.
OTIC: Of, pertaining to, or in the region of, the ear; auricular;auditory.
OLEANDER: A beautiful evergreen shrub of the Dogbane family, havingclusters of fragrant red or white flowers. It is native of the EastIndies, but the red variety has become common in the south of Europe.Called also rosebay, rose laurel, and South-sea rose.
OXYBENZOIC: Hydroxybenzoic; pertaining to, or designating, any one ofseveral hydroxyl derivatives of benzonic acid, of which the commonestis salicylic acid.
OVERLEAVEN: To leaven too much; hence, to change excessively; to spoil.[Obs.]
OBTRUNCATION: The act of lopping or cutting off. [R.] Cockeram.
OARFOOT: Any crustacean of the genus Remipes.
OWLISH: Resembling, or characteristic of, an owl.
OBJECTIVE: Of or pertaining to an object; contained in, or having thenature or position of, an object; outward; external; extrinsic; -- anepithet applied to whatever ir exterior to the mind, or which issimply an object of thought or feeling, and opposed to subjective.In the Middle Ages, subject meant substance, and has this sense inDescartes and Spinoza: sometimes, also, in Reid. Subjective is usedby William of Occam to denote that which exists independent of mind;objective, what is formed by the mind. This shows what is meant byrealitas objectiva in Descartes. Kant and Fichte have inverted themeanings. Subject, with them, is the mind which knows; object, thatwhich is known; subjective, the varying conditions of the knowingmind; objective, that which is in the constant nature of the thingknown. Trendelenburg.Objective means that which belongs to, or proceeds from, the objectknown, and not from the subject knowing, and thus denotes what isreal, in opposition to that which is ideal -- what exists in nature,in contrast to what exists merely in the thought of the individual.Sir. W. Hamilton.Objective has come to mean that which has independent exostence orauthority, apart from our experience or thought. Thus, moral law issaid to have objective authority, that is, authority belonging toitself, and not drawn from anything in our nature. Calderwood(Fleming's Vocabulary).
OROGRAPH: A machine for use in making topographical maps. It is operatedby being pushed across country, and not only records distances, likethe perambulator, but also elevations.
OPAL: A mineral consisting, like quartz, of silica, but inferior toquartz in hardness and specific gravity.
OPPOSITISEPALOUS: Placed in front of a sepal.
OPHIDIA: The order of reptiles which includes the serpents.
OUTSPEED: To excel in speed.Outspeed the realized miracles of steam. Talfourd.
OBLITE: Indistinct; slurred over. [Obs.] "Obscure and oblite mention."Fuller.
ONE: Any person, indefinitely; a person or body; as, what one wouldhave well done, one should do one's self.It was well worth one's while. Hawthorne.Against this sort of condemnation one must steel one's self as onebest can. G. Eliot.
OREGON GRAPE: An evergreen species of barberry (Berberis Aquifolium), ofOregon and California; also, its roundish, blue-black berries.
OVALIFORM: Having the form of an egg; having a figure such that anysection in the direction of the shorter diameter will be circular,and any in the direction of the longer diameter will be oval.
OLIBENE: A colorless mobile liquid of a pleasant aromatic odor obtainedby the distillation of olibanum, or frankincense, and regarded as aterpene; -- called also conimene.
ONSTEAD: A single farmhouse; a steading. [Prov.Eng. & Scot.] Grose.Jamieson.
OUTSETTLER: One who settles at a distance, or away, from others.
ORNITHICHNITE: The footmark of a bird occurring in strata of stone. Hitchcock.
ODOMETROUS: Serving to measure distance on a road. [R.] Sydney Smith.
OVERDRAFT: The act of overdrawing; also, the amount or sum overdrawn.
OMNIPRESENT: Present in all places at the same time; ubiquitous; as, theomnipresent Jehovah. Prior.
OTIS: A genus of birds including the bustards.
OCCIPITOAXIAL: Of or pertaining to the occipital bone and second vertebra, oraxis.
ORCHOTOMY: The operation of cutting out or removing a testicle by theknife; castration.
OPPORTUNIST: One who advocates or practices opportunism. [Recent]
OWENITE: A follower of Robert Owen, who tried to reorganize society on asocialistic basis, and established an industrial community on theClyde, Scotland, and, later, a similar one in Indiana.
ONTOLOGY: That department of the science of metaphysics whichinvestigates and explains the nature and essential properties andrelations of all beings, as such, or the principles and causes ofbeing.
OUTREDE: To surpass in giving rede, or counsel. [Obs.] See Atrede.Chaucer.
OVATION: A lesser kind of triumph allowed to a commander for an easy,bloodless victory, or a victory over slaves.
ORTHOPHONY: The art of correct articulation; voice training.
OCULARY: Of or pertaining to the eye; ocular; optic; as, ocularymedicines. Holland.
OUTGOER: One who goes out or departs.
OXANILIDE: a white crystalline substance, resembling oxanilamide, obtainedby heating aniline oxalate, and regarded as a double anilide ofoxalic acid; -- called also diphenyl oxamide.
OSIRIS: One of the principal divinities of Egypt, the brother andhusband of Isis. He was figured as a mummy wearing the royal cap ofUpper Egypt, and was symbolized by the sacred bull, called Apis. Cf.Serapis.-- O*sir"i*an, a.
OCCASIONABLE: Capable of being occasioned or caused. Barrow.
OLIVA: A genus of polished marine gastropod shells, chiefly tropical,and often beautifully colored.
OVERGROW: To grow beyond the fit or natural size; as, a huge, overgrownox. L'Estrange.
ORTHOMETRIC: Having the axes at right angles to one another; -- said ofcrystals or crystalline forms.
OVERMULTIPLY: To multiply or increase too much; to repeat too often.
ORCHIDOLOGY: The branch of botany which treats of orchids.
OUTFITTER: One who furnishes outfits for a voyage, a journey, or abusiness.
OUTACT: To do or beyond; to exceed in acting. [R.]He has made me heir to treasures Would make me outact a real window'swhining. Otway.
OMISSIVE: Leaving out; omitting. Bp. Hall.-- O*mis"sive*ly, adv.
OXYACID: An acid containing oxygen, as chloric acid or sulphuric acid; -- contrasted with the hydracids, which contain no oxygen, ashydrochloric acid. See Acid, and Hydroxy-.
OUTHOUSE: A small house or building at a little distance from the mainhouse; an outbuilding.
OEIL-DE-PERDRIX: A glance of the eye; an amorous look. [Obs.]She gave strange oeillades and most speaking looks. Shak.
OVERMODEST: Modest to excess; bashful.-- O"ver*mod"est*ly, adv.
OM: A mystic syllable or ejaculation used by Hindus and Buddhistsin religious rites, -- orig. among the Hindus an exclamation ofassent, like Amen, then an invocation, and later a symbol of thetrinity formed by Vishnu, Siva, and Brahma. -- Om mani padme hun, asacred formula of buddhism (esp. of the Lamaists) translated "O, theJewel in the Lotus, Amen," and referring to Amitabha, who is commonlyrepresented as standing or sitting within a lotus.
ORANGE: The tree that bears oranges; the orange tree.
OUTWEIGH: To exceed in weight or value.
ORDNANCE: Heavy weapons of warfare; cannon, or great guns, mortars, andhowitzers; artillery; sometimes, a general term for all weapons andappliances used in war.All the battlements their ordnance fire. Shak.Then you may hear afar off the awful roar of his [Rufus Choate's]rifled ordnance. E. Ererett.Ordnance survey, the official survey of Great Britain and Ireland,conducted by the ordnance department.
ORTHOPEDY: The art or practice of curing the deformities of children, or,by extension, any deformities of the human body.
OUTSOLE: The outside sole of a boot or shoe.
OFFICIARY: Of or pertaining to an office or an officer; official. [R.]Heylin.
OBITER: In passing; incidentally; by the way. Obiter dictum (Law), anincidental and collateral opinion uttered by a judge. See Dictum, n.,2(a).
OVERTAX: To tax or to task too heavily.
ORLO: A wind instrument of music in use among the Spaniards.
ODIST: A writer of an ode or odes.
ORIGINATIVE: Having power, or tending, to originate, or bring intoexistence; originating. H. Bushnell.-- O*rig"i*na*tive*ly, adv.
OPINION: The formal decision, or expression of views, of a judge, anumpire, a counselor, or other party officially called upon toconsider and decide upon a matter or point submitted. To be ofopinion, to think; to judge.-- To hold opinion with, to agree with. [Obs.] Shak.
OREAD: One of the nymphs of mountains and grottoes.Like a wood nymph light, Oread or Dryad. Milton.
OPISTHOBRANCHIATE: Of or pertaining to the Opisthobranchiata.-- n.
OMPHALIC: Of or pertaining to the umbilicus, or navel.
OPE: Open. [Poetic] Spenser.On Sunday heaven's gate stands ope. Herbert.
OVERRULE: To supersede, reject, annul, or rule against; as, the plea, orthe decision, was overruled by the court.
OVATE: Having the shape of an egg, or of the longitudinal sectior ofan egg, with the broader end basal. Gray.
OPENWORK: A quarry; an open cut. Raymond.
OPTIMATES: The nobility or aristocracy of ancient Rome, as opposed to thepopulares.
OVERPAINT: To color or describe too strongly. Sir W. Raleigh.
OBOE: One of the higher wind instruments in the modern orchestra, yetof great antiquity, having a penetrating pastoral quality of tone,somewhat like the clarinet in form, but more slender, and sounded bymeans of a double reed; a hautboy. Oboe d'amore Etym: [It., lit.,oboe of love], and Oboe di caccia Etym: [It., lit., oboe of thechase], are names of obsolete modifications of the oboe, often foundin the scores of Bach and Handel.
OFFICIALISM: The state of being official; a system of official government;also, adherence to office routine; red-tapism.Officialism may often drift into blunders. Smiles.
OUTLAW: A person excluded from the benefit of the law, or deprived ofits protection. Blackstone.
OPHIOMORPHA: An order of tailless amphibians having a slender, wormlike bodywith regular annulations, and usually with minute scales imbedded inthe skin. The limbs are rudimentary or wanting. It includes thecæcilians. Called also Gymnophiona and Ophidobatrachia.
OMINATION: The act of ominating; presaging. [Obs.] Fuller.
OCULINACEA: A suborder of corals including many reef-building species,having round, starlike calicles.
OUTWORK: To exceed in working; to work more or faster than.
OPPOSER: One who opposes; an opponent; an antagonist; an adversary.
OVERBRIM: To flow over the brim; to be so full as to overflow. [R.]
OCTENNIAL: Happening every eighth year; also, lasting a period of eightyears. Johnson.-- Oc*ten"ni*al*ly, adv.
OCULOMOTOR: Of or pertaining to the movement of the eye; -- appliedespecially to the common motor nerves (or third pair of cranialnerves) which supply many of the muscles of the orbit.-- n.
OBSTRUCTIONIST: One who hinders progress; one who obstructs business, as in alegislative body.-- a.
OVIPARITY: Generatuon by means of ova. See Generation.
OENANTHYLIDENE: A colorless liquid hydrocarbon, having a garlic odor; heptine.
ONELINESS: The state of being one or single. [Obs.] Cudworth.
OXYACETIC: Hydroxyacetic; designating an acid called also glycolic acid.
OESTRIAN: Of or pertaining to the gadflies.-- n.
OPHIOMANCY: Divination by serpents, as by their manner of eating, or bytheir coils.
OLEOMETER: An instrument for ascertaining the weight and purity of oil; anelaiometer.
OBSCURANT: One who obscures; one who prevents enlightenment or hinders theprogress of knowledge and wisdom. Coleridge.
OUTTERM: An external or superficial thing; outward manner; superficialremark, etc. [Obs.]Not to bear cold forms, nor men's outterms. B. Jonson.
OVERPROOF: Containing more alcohol than proof spirit; stronger than proofspirit; that is, containing more than 49.3 per cent by weight ofalcohol.
ONCOMETER: An instrument for measuring the variations in size of theinternal organs of the body, as the kidney, spleen, etc.
OTHER: Either; -- used with other or or for its correlative (as either. . . or are now used). [Obs.]Other of chalk, other of glass. Chaucer.
ONOMANCY: Divination by the letters of a name; nomancy. [R.] Camden.
OXFORD: Of or pertaining to the city or university of Oxford, England.Oxford movement. See Tractarianism.-- Oxford School, a name given to those members of the Church ofEngland who adopted the theology of the so-called Oxford "Tracts forthe Times," issued the period 1833 -- 1841. Shipley.-- Oxford tie, a kind of shoe, laced on the instep, and usuallycovering the foot nearly to the ankle.
OVERBURN: To burn too much; to be overzealous.
OVERSLOW: To render slow; to check; to curb. [Obs.] Hammond.
OBOVATE: Inversely ovate; ovate with the narrow end downward; as, anobovate leaf.
OVERLEAP: To leap over or across; hence, to omit; to ignore. "Let meo'erleap that custom." Shak.
ODDMENT: An odd thing, or one that is left over, disconnected,fragmentary, or the like; something that is separated or disconnectedfrom its fellows; esp. (in pl.),
OUTSHINE: To shine forth. "Bright, outshining beams." Shak.
ORTHODOXNESS: The quality or state of being orthodox; orthodoxy. Waterland.
OFFICE WIRE: Copper wire with a strong but light insulation, used in wiringhouses, etc.
OLUSATRUM: An umbelliferous plant, the common Alexanders of Western Europe(Smyrnium Olusatrum).
OBLITERATE: Scarcely distinct; -- applied to the markings of insects.
OPISTHOPULMONATE: Having the pulmonary sac situated posteriorly; -- said ofcertain air-breathing Mollusca.
OXYHYDROGEN LIGHT: A light produced by the incandescence of some substances, esp.lime, in the oxyhydrogen flame. Coal gas (producing the oxygaslight), or the vapor of ether (oxyether light) or methylated spirit(oxyspirit light), may be substituted for hydrogen.
OVERPOWERING: Excelling in power; too powerful; irresistible.-- O`ver*pow"er*ing*ly, adv.
OVERLOAD: To load or fill to excess; to load too heavily.
OSMIOUS: Denoting those compounds of osmium in which the element has avalence relatively lower than in the osmic compounds; as, osmiouschloride. [Written also osmous.] Osmious acid (Chem.), an acidderived from osmium, analogous to sulphurous acid, and formingunstable salts. It is a brown amorphous substance.
OBSERVATION CAR: A railway passenger car made so as to facilitate seeing thescenery en route; a car open, or with glass sides, or with a kind ofopen balcony at the rear.
OBVIATION: The act of obviating, or the state of being obviated.
OUTHAUL: A rope used for hauling out a sail upon a spar; -- opposite ofinhaul.
OVERWEEN: To think too highly or arrogantly; to regard one's own thinkingor conclusions too highly; hence, to egotistic, arrogant, or rash, inopinion; to think conceitedly; to presume.They that overween, And at thy growing virtues fret their spleen.Milton.
OPIANINE: An alkaloid found in small quantity in opium. It is identicalwith narcotine.
OFFICIANT: The officer who officiates or performs an office, as the burialoffice. Shipley.
OYER: A hearing or an inspection, as of a deed, bond, etc., as when adefendant in court prays oyer of a writing. Blackstone. Oyer andterminer (Law), a term used in England in commissions directed tojudges of assize about to hold court, directing them to hear anddetermine cases brought before them. In the U.S. the phrase is usedto designate certain criminal courts.
ORGANIZE: To furnish with organs; to give an organic structure to; toendow with capacity for the functions of life; as, an organizedbeing; organized matter; -- in this sense used chiefly in the pastparticiple.These nobler faculties of the mind, matter organized could neverproduce. Ray.
ORABASSU: A South American monkey of the genus Callithrix, esp. C.Moloch.
ORISKANY: Designating, or pertaining to, certain beds, chiefly limestone,characteristic of the latest period of the Silurian age. Oriskanyperiod, a subdivision of the American Paleozoic system intermediateor translational in character between the Silurian and Devonian ages.See Chart of Geology.
OVERANXIETY: The state of being overanxious; excessive anxiety.
OBCORDATE: Heart-shaped, with the attachment at the pointed end; inverselycordate: as, an obcordate petal or leaf.
ODONTOLITE: A fossil tooth colored a bright blue by phosphate of iron. Itis used as an imitation of turquoise, and hence called boneturquoise.
OUTRUNNER: An offshoot; a branch. [R.] "Some outrunner of the river."Lauson.
OUTLET: The place or opening by which anything is let out; a passageout; an exit; a vent.Receiving all, and having no outlet. Fuller.
OVERCHANGE: Too much or too frequent change; fickleness. [R.] Beau. & Fl.
OPEN-MOUTHED: Having the mouth open; gaping; hence, greedy; clamorous.L'Estrange.
OVERDEAL: The excess. [Obs.]The overdeal in the price will be double. Holland.
OSMATERIUM: One of a pair of scent organs which the larvæ of certainbutterflies emit from the first body segment, either above or below.
OVERSPREAD: To spread over; to cover; as, the deluge overspread the earth.Chaucer.Those nations of the North Which overspread the world. Drayton.
OVERSTRAITLY: Too straitly or strictly. [Obs.] Sir W. Raleigh.
OVERPROMPT: Too prompt; too ready or eager; precipitate.-- O`ver*prompt"ness, n.
ORYCTOGNOSY: Mineralogy. [Obs.] -- Or`yc*tog*nos"tic, a.-- Or`yc*tog*nos"tic*al, a. [Obs.] -- Or`yc*tog*nos"tic*al*ly, adv.[Obs.]
OVERSLIP: To slip or slide over; to pass easily or carelessly beyond; toomit; to neglect; as, to overslip time or opportunity.
OBLATIONER: One who makes an offering as an act worship or reverence. Dr.H. More.
OGYGIAN: Of or pertaining to Ogyges, a mythical king of ancient Attica,or to a great deluge in Attica in his days; hence, primeval; ofobscure antiquity.
OUTSTREET: A street remote from the center of a town. Johnson.
OXPECKER: An African bird of the genus Buphaga; the beefeater.
OMPHALOMESENTERIC: Of or pertaining to the umbilicus and mesentery;omphalomesaraic; as, the omphalomesenteric arteries and veins of afetus.
OCCIDENT: The part of the horizon where the sun last appears in theevening; that part of the earth towards the sunset; the west; --opposed to orient. Specifically, in former times, Europe as opposedto Asia; now, also, the Western hemisphere. Chaucer.I may wander from east to occident. Shak.
OGRE: An imaginary monster, or hideous giant of fairy tales, wholived on human beings; hence, any frightful giant; a cruel monster.His schoolroom must have resembled an ogre's den. Maccaulay.
OBTUSENESS: State or quality of being obtuse.
OUTZANY: To exceed in buffoonery. [Obs.] B. Jonson.
OUTRANK: To exceed in rank; hence, to take precedence of.
OVERFEED: To feed to excess; to surfeit.
OILSTONE: A variety of hone slate, or whetstone, used for whetting toolswhen lubricated with oil.
OOECIUM: One of the special zooids, or cells, of Bryozoa, destined toreceive and develop ova; an ovicell. See Bryozoa.
OECOLOGY: The various relations of animals and plants to one another andto the outer world.
