OVERHAUL: To gain upon in a chase; to overtake. To overhaul a tackle, topull on the leading parts so as to separate the blocks.-- To overhaul running rigging, to keep it clear, and see that nohitch occurs.
OFFICIATE: To act as an officer in performing a duty; to transact thebusiness of an office or public trust; to conduct a public service.Bp. Stillingfleet.
OCCRUSTATE: To incrust; to harden. [Obs.] Dr. H. More.
OUTSPREAD: To spread out; to expand; -- usually as a past part. or adj.
OPUNTIA: A genus of cactaceous plants; the prickly pear, or Indian fig.
OVERPERCH: To perch upon; to fly over. [Obs.] Shak.
OMNISCIENCE: The quality or state of being omniscient; -- an attributepeculiar to God. Dryden.
OCTAMEROUS: Having the parts in eights; as, an octamerous flower;octamerous mesenteries in polyps.
OCULIFORM: In the form of an eye; resembling an eye; as, an oculiformpebble.
OTO-: A combining form denoting relation to, or situation near or in,the ear.
OILINESS: The quality of being oily. Bacon.
ORTHID: A brachiopod shell of the genus Orthis, and allied genera, ofthe family Orthidæ.
OCTOYL: A hypothetical radical (C8H15O), regarded as the essentialresidue of octoic acid.
OPEN-HEARTED: Candid; frank; generous. Dryden.-- O"pen-heart`ed*ly, adv.-- O"pen-heart`ed*ness, n. Walton.
ORATORIZE: To play the orator. [Jocose or derisive] Dickens.
ORDINARYSHIP: The state of being an ordinary. [R.] Fuller.
ORTHOPEDIST: One who prevents, cures, or remedies deformities, esp. inchildren.
OSMAZOME: A substance formerly supposed to give to soup and broth theircharacteristic odor, and probably consisting of one or several of theclass of nitrogenous substances which are called extractives.
OVERSMAN: An umpire; a third arbiter, appointed when two arbiters,previously selected, disagree.
OVEN: A place arched over with brick or stonework, and used forbaking, heating, or drying; hence, any structure, whether fixed orportable, which may be heated for baking, drying, etc.; esp., now, achamber in a stove, used for baking or roasting.
OUTWALK: To excel in walking; to leave behind in walking. B. Jonson.
OXALAN: A complex nitrogenous substance C3N3H5O3 obtained from alloxan(or when urea is fused with ethyl oxamate), as a stable whitecrystalline powder; -- called also oxaluramide.
OBIMBRICATE: Imbricated, with the overlapping ends directed downward.
OBSTETRICATION: The act of assisting as a midwife; delivery. [Obs.] Bp. Hall.
OBVERSE: Having the base, or end next the attachment, narrower than thetop, as a leaf.
OBUMBRATE: To shade; to darken; to cloud. [R.] Howell.
OKAPI: A peculiar mammal (Okapia johnostoni) closely related to thegiraffe, discovered in the deep forests of Belgian Kongo in 1900. Itis smaller than an ox, and somewhat like a giraffe, except that theneck is much shorter. Like the giraffe, it has no dewclaws. There isa small prominence on each frontal bone of the male. The color of thebody is chiefly reddish chestnut, the cheeks are yellowish white, andthe fore and hind legs above the knees and the haunches are stripedwith purplish black and cream color.
OVERLORD: One who is lord over another or others; a superior lord; amaster. Freeman.
OXYMURIATE: A salt of the supposed oxymuriatic acid; a chloride. Oxymuriateof lime, chloride of lime.
OGLE: To view or look at with side glances, as in fondness, or with adesign to attract notice.And ogling all their audience, ere they speak. Dryden.
OMBRE: A large Mediterranean food fish (Umbrina cirrhosa): -- calledalso umbra, and umbrine.
ORDINARILY: According to established rules or settled method; as a rule;commonly; usually; in most cases; as, a winter more than ordinarilysevere.Those who ordinarily pride themselves not a little upon theirpenetration. I. Taylor.
OXHEART: A large heart-shaped cherry, either black, red, or white.
ORGAN: A natural part or structure in an animal or a plant, capable ofperforming some special action (termed its function), which isessential to the life or well-being of the whole; as, the heart,lungs, etc., are organs of animals; the root, stem, foliage, etc.,are organs of plants.
OZONE PAPER: Paper coated with starch and potassium iodine. It turns bluewhen exposed to ozone.>-- also called starch-iodide paper -->
OXIDABILITY: Capability of being converted into an oxide.
OSTOSIS: Bone formation; ossification. See Ectostosis, and Endostosis.
ORTHODROMY: The act or art of sailing on a great circle.
OPISTHOMI: An order of eellike fishes having the scapular arch attached tothe vertebræ, but not connected with the skull.
ONE-SIDED: Growing on one side of a stem; as, one-sided flowers.-- One`-sid"ed-ly, adv.-- One`-sid"ed*ness, n.
OBLIGER: One who, or that which, obliges. Sir H. Wotton.
OBLONGATA: The medulla oblongata. B. G. Wilder.
OVERSTAND: To stand on the price or conditions of, so as to lose a sale;to lose by an extravagant price or hard conditions. [Obs.]What madman would o'erstand his market twice Dryden.
OENANTHIC: Having, or imparting, the odor characteristic of the bouquet ofwine; specifically used, formerly, to designate an acid whoseethereal salts were supposed to occasion the peculiar bouquet, oraroma, of old wine. Cf. OEnanthylic. OEnanthic acid, an acid obtainedfrom oenanthic ether by the action of alkalies.-- OEnanthic ether, an ethereal substance (not to be confused withthe bouquet, or aroma, of wine) found in wine lees, and consisting ofa complex mixture of the ethereal salts of several of the higheracids of the acetic acid series. It has an ethereal odor, and it usedin flavoring artificial wines and liquors. Called also oil of wine.See Essential oil, under Essential.
OPALESCE: To give forth a play of colors, like the opal.
OCTACHORD: An instrument of eight strings; a system of eight tones. [Alsowritten octochord.]
ONUS: A burden; an obligation. Onus probandi ( Etym: [L.], obligationto furnish evidence to prove a thing; the burden of proof.
OZONIFICATION: The act or process of producing, or of subjecting to the actionof, ozone.
OUANANICHE: A small landlocked variety of the Atlantic salmon (Salmo salarounaniche) of Lake St. John, Canada, and neighboring waters, notedfor its vigor and activity, and habit of leaping from the water whenhooked.
OMBROMETER: An instrument for measuring the rain that falls; a rain gauge.
ONIONSKIN: A kind of thin translucent paper with a glossy finish.
OPIANIC: Of, pertaining to, or designating, an organic acid obtained bythe oxidation of narcotine.
ORGANICAL: Organic.The organical structure of human bodies, whereby they live and move.Bentley.
ORNITHICHNOLOGY: The branch of science which treats of ornithichnites.Hitchcock.
OTTOMAN: Of or pertaining to the Turks; as, the Ottoman power or empire.
OPPOSABILITY: The condition or quality of being opposable.In no savage have I ever seen the slightest approach to opposabilityof the great toe, which is the essential distinguishing feature ofapes. A. R. Wallace.
OVERWEAR: To wear too much; to wear out. Drayton.
OUTPORT: A harbor or port at some distance from the chief town or seatof trade. Macaulay.
OVERTHWARTNESS: The state of being overthwart; perverseness. [Obs.] LordHerbert.
ORTHOGRAPH: An orthographic projection, sometimes partly in section, esp.of a building.
OMMATIDIUM: One of the single eyes forming the compound eyes ofcrustaceans, insects, and other invertebrates.
OZONOMETER: An instrument for ascertaining the amount of ozone in theatmosphere, or in any gaseous mixture. Faraday.
ORTHOCERATITE: An orthoceras; also, any fossil shell allied to Orthoceras.
OCCASIONALISM: The system of occasional causes; -- a name given to certaintheories of the Cartesian school of philosophers, as to theintervention of the First Cause, by which they account for theapparent reciprocal action of the soul and the body.
ORTHOGAMY: Direct fertilization in plants, as when the pollen fertilizingthe ovules comes from the stamens of the same blossom; -- opposed toheterogamy.
ORTHODOXLY: In an orthodox manner; with soundness of faith. Sir W.Hamilton.
OXAMIDE: A white crystalline neutral substance (C2O2(NH2)2) obtained bytreating ethyl oxalate with ammonia. It is the acid amide of oxalicacid. Formerly called also oxalamide.
OUTSET: A setting out, starting, or beginning. "The outset of apolitical journey." Burke.Giving a proper direction to this outset of life. J. Hawes.
OZONIC: Pertaining to, resembling, or containing, ozone.
OPTION: A right formerly belonging to an archbishop to select any onedignity or benefice in the gift of a suffragan bishop consecrated orconfirmed by him, for bestowal by himself when next vacant; --annulled by Parliament in 1845.
ORCHESTRA: The instruments employed by a full band, collectively; as, anorchestra of forty stringed instruments, with proper complement ofwind instruments.
OPPONENCY: The act of opening an academical disputation; the propositionof objections to a tenet, as an exercise for a degree. [Eng.] Todd.
OCTANT: The eighth part of a circle; an arc of 45 degrees.
OROLOGY: The science or description of mountains.
ORDINALISM: The state or quality of being ordinal. [R.] Latham.
OVERDUE: Due and more than due; delayed beyond the proper time ofarrival or payment, etc.; as, an overdue vessel; an overdue note.
OPERATIVE: Based upon, or consisting of, an operation or operations; as,operative surgery.
OSIER: Made of osiers; composed of, or containing, osiers. "This osiercage of ours." Shak.
OHMMETER: An instrument for indicating directly resistance in ohms.
OUSTER: A putting out of possession; dispossession; ejection;disseizin.Ouster of the freehold is effected by abatement, intrusion,disseizin, discontinuance, or deforcement. Blackstone.Ouster le main. Etym: [Ouster + F. la main the hand, L. manus.] (Law)A delivery of lands out of the hands of a guardian, or out of theking's hands, or a judgement given for that purpose. Blackstone.
OVERMAGNIFY: To magnify too much. Bp. Hall.
OUTRUSH: To rush out; to issue, or ru Garth.
OCTAD: An atom or radical which has a valence of eight, or isoctavalent.
OCULIST: One skilled in treating diseases of the eye.
OUTPACE: To outgo; to move faster than; to leave behind. [R.] Lamb.
OXINDOL: A white crystalline nitrogenous substance (C8H7NO) of the indolgroup, obtained by the reduction of dioxindol. It is a so-calledlactam compound.
OLEANDRINE: One of several alkaloids found in the leaves of the oleander.
OAR: An oarlike swimming organ of various invertebrates. Oar cock(Zoöl), the water rail. [Prov. Eng.] -- Spoon oar, an oar having theblade so curved as to afford a better hold upon the water in rowing.-- To boat the oars, to cease rowing, and lay the oars in the boat.-- To feather the oars. See under Feather., v. t.-- To lie on the oars, to cease pulling, raising the oars out ofwater, but not boating them; to cease from work of any kind; to beidle; to rest.-- To muffle the oars, to put something round that part which restsin the rowlock, to prevent noise in rowing.-- To put in one's oar, to give aid or advice; -- commonly used of aperson who obtrudes aid or counsel not invited.-- To ship the oars, to place them in the rowlocks.-- To toss the oars, To peak the oars, to lift them from therowlocks and hold them perpendicularly, the handle resting on thebottom of the boat.-- To trail oars, to allow them to trail in the water alongside ofthe boat.-- To unship the oars, to take them out of the rowlocks.
OVERFRONT: To confront; to oppose; to withstand. [Obs.] Milton.
ORATORY: A place of orisons, or prayer; especially, a chapel or smallroom set apart for private devotions.An oratory [temple] . . . in worship of Dian. Chaucer.Do not omit thy prayers for want of a good oratory, or place to prayin. Jer. Taylor.Fathers of the Oratory (R. C. Ch.), a society of priests founded bySt. Philip Neri, living in community, and not bound by a special vow.The members are called also oratorians.
ORGANOGRAPHY: A description of the organs of animals or plants.
OBSOLETISM: A disused word or phrase; an archaism. Fitzed. Hall.
OUTARGUE: To surpass or conquer in argument.
OCTOPETALOUS: Having eight petals or flower leaves.
ORIENTALIZE: to render Oriental; to cause to conform to Oriental manners orconditions.
OPINIONABLE: Being, or capable of being, a matter of opinion; that can bethought; not positively settled; as, an opinionable doctrine. C. J.Ellicott.
OVERABOUND: To be exceedingly plenty or superabundant. Pope.
OUTWREST: To extort; to draw from or forth by violence. [Obs.] Spenser.
ORGANISM: An organized being; a living body, either vegetable or animal,compozed of different organs or parts with functions which areseparate, but mutually dependent, and essential to the life of theindividual.
ONOMATOLOGY: The science of names or of their classification.
OGEE: A molding, the section of which is the form of the letter S,with the convex part above; cyma reversa. See Illust. under Cyma.
ONCIDIUM: A genus of tropical orchidaceous plants, the flower of onespecies of which (O. Papilio) resembles a butterfly.
OBTRUNCATE: To deprive of a limb; to lop. [R.]
ONEIROMANCY: Divination by means of dreams. De Quincey.
ORTHOGRAPHIZE: To spell correctly or according to usage; to correct in regardto spelling.In the coalesced into ith, which modern reaction has orthographizedto i' th'. Earle.
ONOMATOPOETIC: Of or pertaining to onomatopoeia; characterized byonomatopoeia; imitative; as, an onomatopoetic writer or word. Earle.
ORBICULATION: The state or quality of being orbiculate; orbicularness. Dr. H.More.
OVERRATE: To rate or value too highly.
OBLONG-OVATE: Between oblong and ovate, but inclined to the latter.
OUTTRAVEL: To exceed in speed o Mad. D' Arblay.
ONWARD: Toward a point before or in front; forward; progressively; as,to move onward.Not one looks backward, onward still he goes. Pope.
OXEYED: Having large, full eyes, like those of an ox. Burton.
OROTUND: Characterized by fullness, clearness, strength, and smoothness;ringing and musical; -- said of the voice or manner of utterance.-- n.
ORPHANHOOD: The state or condition of being an orphan; orphanage.
ORPHREY: A band of rich embroidery, wholly or in part of gold, affixedto vestments, especially those of ecclesiastics. Pugin.
OXONIC: Pertaining to, or designating, a complex nitrogenous acid(C4H5N3O4) not known in the free state, but obtained, in combinationwith its salts, by a slow oxidation of uric acid, to which it isrelated.
OLDEN: Old; ancient; as, the olden time. "A minstrel of the oldenstamp." J. C. Shairp.
OCCASIONER: One who, or that which, occasions, causes, or produces. Bp.Sanderson.
ORTHOGRAPHICALLY: In an orthographical manner:(a) according to the rules of proper spelling;(b) according to orthographic projection.
OPINIONIST: One fond of his own notions, or unduly attached to his ownopinions. Glanvill.
ODS: A corruption of God's; -- formerly used in oaths andejaculatory phrases. "Ods bodikin." "Ods pity." Shak.
ORTHOPODA: An extinct order of reptiles which stood erect on the hindlegs, and resembled birds in the structure of the feet, pelvis, andother parts.
ONOMASTICON: A collection of names and terms; a dictionary; specif., acollection of Greek names, with explanatory notes, made by JuliusPollux about A.D.180.
OILERY: The business, the place of business, or the goods, of a makerof, or dealer in, oils.
OUTSCOURING: That which is scoured out o Buckland.
ORKNEYAN: Of or pertaining to the Orkney islands. "Orkneyan skerries."Longfellow.
OATHABLE: Capable of having an oath administered to. [Obs.] Shak.
ONOMATOPOEIA: The formation of words in imitation of sounds; a figure ofspeech in which the sound of a word is imitative of the sound of thething which the word represents; as, the buzz of bees; the hiss of agoose; the crackle of fire.
OVERRULING: Exerting controlling power; as, an overruling Providence.-- O`ver*rul"ing*ly, adv.
OVERSTEP: To step over or beyond; to transgress. Shak.
OBLONG: Having greater length than breadth, esp. when rectangular.
OGIVE: The arch or rib which crosses a Gothic vault diagonally.
OVERSLAUGH: A bar in a river; as, the overslaugh in the Hudson River.[Local, U. S.] Bartlett.
OCTAGYNOUS: Having eight pistils or styles; octogynous.
OSMIAMIC: Of, pertaining to, or designating, a nitrogenous acid ofosmium, H2N2Os2O5, forming a well-known series of yellow salts.
OVERTONE: One of the harmonics faintly heard with and above a tone as itdies away, produced by some aliquot portion of the vibrating sting orcolumn of air which yields the fundamental tone; one of the naturalharmonic scale of tones, as the octave, twelfth, fifteenth, etc.; analiquot or "partial" tone; a harmonic. See Harmonic, and Tone.Tyndall.
OSTEOCOMMA: A metamere of the vertebrate skeleton; an osteomere; avertebra. Owen.
OVERFLY: To cross or pass over by flight. Byron.
OFFSET: In general, that which is set off, from, before, or against,something; as: --
OAKEN: Made or consisting of oaks or of the wood of oaks. "In oakenbower." Milton.Oaken timber, wherewith to build ships. Bacon.
ORMOLU: A variety of brass made to resemble gold by the use of lesszinc and more copper in its composition than ordinary brass contains.Its golden color is often heightened by means of lacquer of somesort, or by use of acids. Called also mosaic gold. Ormolu varnish, avarnish applied to metals, as brass, to give the appearance of gold.
OZONOSCOPIC: Serving to indicate the presence or the amount of ozone.
ORGY: A frantic revel; drunken revelry. See Orgies
OVERGLOOM: To spread gloom over; to make gloomy; to overshadow. [R.]Overgloomed by memories of sorrow. De Quincey.
OUTPARISH: A parish lying without the walls of, or in a remote part of, atown. Graunt.
OPINE: To have an opinion; to judge; to think; to suppose. South.
ORGANOTROPHIC: Relating to the creation, organization, and nutrition of livingorgans or parts.
OPHIURIOID: Of or pertaining to the Ophiurioidea.-- n.
OVERFLOWING: An overflow; that which overflows; exuberance; copiousness.He was ready to bestow the overflowings of his full mind on anybodywho would start a subject. Macaulay.
OCTAHEDRITE: Titanium dioxide occurring in acute octahedral crystals.
OCTOFID: Cleft or separated into eight segments, as a calyx.
OPALESCENT: Reflecting a milky or pearly light from the interior; having anopaline play of colors.
OXYTOCIC: Promoting uterine contractions, or parturition.-- n.
ORVIETAN: A kind of antidote for poisons; a counter poison formerly invogue. [Obs.]
OVERREACHER: One who overreaches; one who cheats; a cheat.
OF: In a general sense, from, or out from; proceeding from;belonging to; relating to; concerning; -- used in a variety ofapplications; as:
OVERBOLD: Excessively or presumptuously bold; impudent. Shak.-- O"ver*bold"ly, adv.
OFFCUT: A portion ofthe printed sheet, in certain sizes of books, thatis cut off before folding.
OPPORTUNISM: The art or practice of taking advantage of opportunities orcircumstances, or of seeking immediate advantage with little regardfor ultimate consequences. [Recent]
OLERACEOUS: Pertaining to pot herbs; of the nature or having the qualitiesof herbs for cookery; esculent. Sir T. Browne.
OMNIUM: The aggregate value of the different stocks in which a loan togovernment is now usually funded. M'Culloch.
OUTSIDE: or prep. On or to the outside (of); without; on the exterior;as, to ride outside the coach; he stayed outside.
OUTDOOR: Being, or done, in the open air; being or done outside ofcertain buildings, as poorhouses, hospitals, etc.; as, outdoorexercise; outdoor relief; outdoor patients.
OVERPOISE: To outweigh; to overbalance. [R.] Sir T. Browne.
OVERHIP: To pass over by, or as by a hop; to skip over; hence, tooverpass. [Obs.] "When the time is overhipt." Holland.
ORIENTALITY: The quality or state of being oriental or eastern. Sir T.Browne.
ORNITHIC: Of or pertaining to birds; as, ornithic fossils. Owen.
ONGOING: The act of going forward; progress; (pl.) affairs; business;current events.The common ongoings of this our commonplace world, and everyday life.Prof. Wilson.
ODONTOBLAST: One of the more or less columnar cells on the outer surface ofthe pulp of a tooth; an odontoplast. They are supposed to beconnected with the formation of dentine.
OXAMETHYLANE: Methyl oxamate, obtained as a pearly white crystallinesubstance.
OPTOGRAPHY: The production of an optogram on the retina by thephotochemical action of light on the visual purple; the fixation ofan image in the eye. The object so photographed shows white on apurple or red background. See Visual purple, under Visual.
OVERDARE: To dare too much or rashly; to be too daring.
OPERCULIFORM: Having the form of a lid or cover.
OUTRANCE: The utmost or last extremity. Combat à outrance, a fight to theend, or to the death.
OVARIOTOMIST: One who performs, or is skilled in, ovariotomy.
ONOMATOLOGIST: One versed in the history of names. Southey.
ORDINATIVE: Tending to ordain; directing; giving order. [R.] Gauden.
OXYGEN: A colorless, tasteless, odorless, gaseous element occurring inthe free state in the atmosphere, of which it forms about 23 per centby weight and about 21 per cent by volume, being slightly heavierthan nitrogen. Symbol O. Atomic weight 15.96.
OUTSTAND: To stand out, or project, from a surface or mass; hence, toremain standing out.
OVERLADE: To load with too great a cargo; to overburden; to overload.Spenser.
OBSCURANTISM: The system or the principles of the obscurants. C. Kingsley.
OPALINE: Of, pertaining to, or like, opal in appearance; havingchangeable colors like those of the opal.
ORD: An edge or point; also, a beginning. [ Obs. or Prov. Eng.]Chaucer. Ord and end, the beginning and end. Cf. Odds and ends, underOdds. [Obs. or Prov. Eng.] Chaucer. Halliwell.
OVERBEAR: To bear fruit or offspring to excess; to be too prolific.
ORDERLY: According to due order; regularly; methodically; duly.You are blunt; go to it orderly. Shak.
ODONTOLOGY: The science which treats of the teeth, their structure anddevelopment.
OUTFIELD: The part of the field beyond the diamond, or infield. It isoccupied by the fielders.
ODMYL: A volatile liquid obtained by boiling sulphur with linseed oil.It has an unpleasant garlic odor.
ORNITHOSCOPY: Observation of birds and their habits. [R.] De Quincey.
OCCASION: To give occasion to; to cause; to produce; to induce; as, tooccasion anxiety. South.If we inquire what it is that occasions men to make severalcombinations of simple ideas into distinct modes. Locke.
ORYX: A genus of African antelopes which includes the gemsbok, theleucoryx, the bisa antelope (O. beisa), and the beatrix antelope (O.beatrix) of Arabia.
OVERMASTER: To overpower; to subdue; to vanquish; to govern.
OXYMEL: A mixture of honey, water, vinegar, and spice, boiled to asirup. Sir T. Elyot.
OUTFOOT: To outrun or outwalk; hence, of a vessel, to outsail. [Colloq.]
OSTRACEAN: Any one of a family of bivalves, of which the oyster is thetype.
OPTIMISTIC: Of or pertaining to optimism; tending, or conforming, to theopinion that all events are ordered for the best.
ORATORICAL: Of or pertaining to an orator or to oratory; characterized byoratory; rhetorical; becoming to an orator; as, an oratoricaltriumph; an oratorical essay.-- Or`a*tor"ic*al*ly, adv.
OVERCONFIDENCE: Excessive confidence; too great reliance or trust.
ONEROUS: Burdensome; oppressive. "Too onerous a solicitude." I. Taylor.Onerous cause (Scots Law), a good and legal consideration; -- opposedto gratuitous.
OVERFORWARD: Forward to excess; too forward.-- O"ver*for"ward*ness, n.
OUTBRAZEN: To bear down with a brazen face; to surpass in impudence. T.Brown.
OVERESTIMATE: To estimate too highly; to overvalue.
OCHLESIS: A general morbid condition induced by the crowding together ofmany persons, esp. sick persons, under one roof. G. Gregory.
OLIGOCHETE: Of or pertaining to the Oligochæta.
OSTRACEA: A division of bivalve mollusks including the oysters and alliedshells.
OVERGRACE: To grace or honor exceedingly or beyond desert. [R.] Beau. &Fl.
OPPOSELESS: Not to be effectually opposed; irresistible. [Obs.] "Your greatopposeless wills." Shak.
OTTRELITE: A micaceous mineral occurring in small scales. It ischaracteristic of certain crystalline schists.
OZONATION: The act of treating with ozone; also, the act of convertinginto, or producing, ozone; ozonization.
OREOSOMA: A genus of small oceanic fishes, remarkable for the largeconical tubercles which cover the under surface.
OPHTHALMOLOGIST: One skilled in ophthalmology; an oculist.
ORDEAL: Of or pertaining to trial by ordeal.
ORTHOGONAL: Right-angled; rectangular; as, an orthogonal intersection ofone curve with another. Orthogonal projection. See underOrthographic.
OESTRUAL: Of or pertaining to sexual desire; -- mostly applied to bruteanimals; as, the oestrual period; oestrual influence.
OCTOGENARY: Of eighty years of age. "Being then octogenary." Aubrey.
OPERATION: Something to be done; some transformation to be made uponquantities, the transformation being indicated either by rules orsymbols.
ORDINATE: Well-ordered; orderly; regular; methodical. "A life blissfuland ordinate." Chaucer. Ordinate figure (Math.), a figure whose sidesand angles are equal; a regular figure.
ONCOGRAPH: An instrument for registering the changes observable with anoncometer.
OBEQUITATE: To ride about. [Obs.] -- Ob*eq`ui*ta"tion, n. [Obs.] Cockerman.
OVERPOST: To post over; to pass over swiftly, as by post. Shak.
OVERVOTE: To outvote; to outnumber in votes given. [R.] Eikon Basilike.
OBSERVATORY: A lookout on a flank of a battery whence an officer can notethe range and effect of the fire. Farrow.
OZONIZER: An apparatus or agent for the production or application ofozone.
ORA: A money of account among the Anglo-Saxons, valued, in theDomesday Book, at twenty pence sterling.
OVERTIME: Time beyond, or in excess of, a limit; esp., extra workingtime.
OBLATUM: An oblate spheroid; a figure described by the revolution of anellipse about its minor axis. Cf. Oblongum.
OUTQUENCH: To quench entirely; to extinguish. "The candlelightoutquenched." Spenser.
OBREPTION: The obtaining gifts of escheat by fraud or surprise. Bell.
OUTERMOST: Being on the extreme external part; farthest outward; as, theoutermost row. Boyle.
OUTWING: To surpass, exceed, or outstrip in flying. Garth.
OWLER: One who owls; esp., one who conveys contraband goods. SeeOwling, n. [Obs. or Prov. Eng.] T. Brown.
OXHIDE: A measure of land. See 3d Hide.
OCTODONT: Of or pertaining to the Octodontidæ, a family of rodents whichincludes the coypu, and many other South American species.
OSTEOCRANIUM: The bony cranium, as distinguished from the cartilaginouscranium.
OBSCURATION: The act or operation of obscuring; the state of being obscured;as, the obscuration of the moon in an eclipse. Sir J. Herschel.
OCCULTNESS: State or quality of being occult.
ORTALIDIAN: Any one of numerous small two-winged flies of the familyOrtalidæ. The larvæ of many of these flies live in fruit; those ofothers produce galls on various plants.
OCCECATION: The act of making blind, or the state of being blind. [R.]"This inward occecation." Bp. Hall.
ORGANISTA: Any one of several South American wrens, noted for thesweetness of their song.
OSTRACOIDEA: An order of Entomostraca possessing hard bivalve shells. Theyare of small size, and swim freely about. [Written also Ostracoda.]
OGDOASTICH: A poem of eight lines. [Obs.] Selden
OVERTURN: The act off overturning, or the state of being overturned orsubverted; overthrow; as, an overturn of parties.
OFFENSIVE: The state or posture of one who offends or makes attack;aggressive attitude; the act of the attacking party; -- opposed todefensive. To act on the offensive, to be the attacking party.
OXIODIC: Pertaining to, or designating, certain compounds of iodine andoxygen.
OORDOBA: The monetary unit of Nicaragua, equivalent to the United Statesgold dollar.
OSCILLOMETER: An instrument for measuring the angle through which a shiprolls or pitches at sea.
OOP: To bind with a thread or cord; to join; to unite. [Scot.]Jamieson.
OCTOSTYLE: Having eight columns in the front; -- said of a temple orportico. The Parthenon is octostyle, but most large Greek temples arehexastele. See Hexastyle.-- n.
OPEN-HANDED: Generous; liberal; munificent.-- O"pen-hand`ed*ness, n. J. S. Mill.
OSTEOPTERYGIOUS: Having bones in the fins, as certain fishes.
ORDAINABLE: Capable of being ordained; worthy to be ordained or appointed.Bp. Hall.
OPERCULIGENOUS: Producing an operculum; -- said of the foot, or part of thefoot, of certain mollusks.
OVERAWFUL: Awful, or reverential, in an excessive degree. [R.] Milton.
OMAHAS: A tribe of Indians who inhabited the south side of the MissouriRiver. They are now partly civilized and occupy a reservation inNebraska.
OPTICALLY: By optics or sight; with reference to optics. Optically active,Optically inactive (Chem. Physics), terms used of certain metamericsubstances which, while identical with each other in other respects,differ in this, viz., that they do or do not produce right-handed orleft-handed circular polarization of light.-- Optically positive, Optically negative. See under Refraction.
OSSEAN: A fish having a bony skeleton; a teleost.
OBSTREPEROUS: Attended by, or making, a loud and tumultuous noise; clamorous;noisy; vociferous. "The obstreperous city." Wordsworth. "Obstreperousapprobation." Addison.Beating the air with their obstreperous beaks. B. Jonson.-- Ob*strep"er*ous*ly, adv.-- Ob*strep"er*ous*ness, n.
OLD-MAIDISH: Like an old maid; prim; precise; particular.
OUTDARE: To surpass in daring; to overcome by courage; to brave. Shak.R. Browning.
OVERLANDER: One who travels over lands or countries; one who travelsoverland.
OUZEL: Same as Ousel.The mellow ouzel fluted in the elm. Tennyson.
OMEGOID: Having the form of the Greek capital letter Omega (
OVERPAY: To pay too much to; to reward too highly.
ORBITAL: Of or pertaining to an orbit. "Orbital revolution." J. D.Forbes. Orbital index (Anat.), in the skull, the ratio of thevertical height to the transverse width of the orbit, which is takenas the standard, equal to 100.
OPENNESS: The quality or state of being open.
OTHERGATES: In another manner. [Obs.]He would have tickled you othergates. Shak.
OVERDOSE: To dose to excess; to give an overdose, or too many doses, to.
ORBITOSPHENOID: Of or pertaining to the sphenoid bone and the orbit, or to theorbitosphenoid bone.-- n.
ORBIT: The path described by a heavenly body in its periodicalrevolution around another body; as, the orbit of Jupiter, of theearth, of the moon.
OVICELL: One of the dilatations of the body wall of Bryozoa in which theova sometimes undegro the first stages of their development. SeeIllust. of Chilostoma.
OLEO OIL: An oil expressed from certain animal fats (esp. beef suet), thegreater portion of the solid fat, or stearin, being left behind. Itis mixture of olein, palmitin, and a little stearin.
OXLIKE: Characteristic of, or like, an ox.
OFFHAND: Instant; ready; extemporaneous; as, an offhand speech; offhandexcuses.-- adv.
OTOLOGIST: One skilled in otology; an aurist.
OMMATEAL: Of or pertaining to an ommateum.
ORGANOPHYLY: The tribal history of organs, -- a branch of morphophyly.Haeckel.
OMNIPRESENCE: Presence in every place at the same time; unbounded oruniversal presence; ubiquity.His omnipresence fills Land, sea, and air, and every kind that lives.Milton.
OFFISH: Shy or distant in manner. [Colloq. U.S.]
OCTONARY: Of or pertaining to the number eight. Dr. H. More.
OKENITE: A massive and fibrous mineral of a whitish color, chieflyhydrous silicate of lime.
OAF: Originally, an elf's child; a changeling left by fairies orgoblins; hence, a deformed or foolish child; a simpleton; an idiot.
OPHTHALMIA: An inflammation of the membranes or coats of the eye or of theeyeball.
OVERHELE: To hele or cover over. [Obs.] B. Jonson.
OBLONGNESS: State or quality of being oblong.
OUT: In its original and strict sense, out means from the interiorof something; beyond the limits or boundary of somethings; in aposition or relation which is exterior to something; -- opposed to inor into. The something may be expressed after of, from, etc. (see Outof, below); or, if not expressed, it is implied; as, he is out; or,he is out of the house, office, business, etc.; he came out; or, hecame out from the ship, meeting, sect, party, etc. Out is used in avariety of applications, as: --
OBELUS: A mark [thus ---, or ÷]; -- so called as resembling a needle.In old MSS. or editions of the classics, it marks suspected passagesor readings.
ORNITHON: An aviary; a poultry house. Weale.
OVERLAND: Being, or accomplished, over the land, instead of by sea; as,an overland journey.
OVERTEMPT: To tempt exceedingly, or beyond the power of resistance.Milton.
ODAL: Among the early and medieval Teutonic peoples, esp.Scandinavians, the heritable land held by the various odalmenconstituting a family or kindred of freeborn tribesmen; also, theownership of such land. The odal was subject only to certain rightsof the family or kindred in restricting the freedom of transfer orsale and giving certain rights of redemption in case of change ofownership by inheritance, etc., and perhaps to other rights of thekindred or the tribe. Survivals of the early odal estates and tenureexist in Orkney and Shetland, where it is usually called by thevariant form udal.
OBTECTED: Covered with a hard chitinous case, as the pupa of certainfiles.
OXALANTIN: A white crystalline nitrogenous substance (C6H4N4O5) obtainedby the reduction of parabanic acid; -- called also leucoturic acid.
OFFICER: Specifically, a commissioned officer, in distinction from awarrant officer. Field officer, General officer, etc. See underField, General. etc.-- Officer of the day (Mil.), the officer who, on a given day, hascharge for that day of the quard, prisoners, and police of the postor camp.-- Officer of the deck, or Officer of the watch (Naut.), the officertemporarily in charge on the deck of a vessel, esp. a war vessel.
ORNITHOSAURIA: An order of extinct flying reptiles; -- called alsoPterosauria.
OVERSWELL: To swell or rise above; to overflow. [R.] Shak.
OMANDER WOOD: The wood of Diospyros ebenaster, a kind of ebony found inCeylon.
ORTHORHOMBIC: Noting the system of crystallization which has three unequalaxes at right angles to each other; trimetric. See Crystallization.
OVERPRODUCTION: Excessive production; supply beyond the demand. J. S. Mill.
OLIVERIAN: An adherent of Oliver Cromwell. Macaulay.
OLEONE: An oily liquid, obtained by distillation of calcium oleate, andprobably consisting of the ketone of oleic acid.
OVERRULER: One who, or that which, controls, governs, or determines. SirP. Sidney.
OUBLIETTE: A dungeon with an opening only at the top, found in some oldcastles and other strongholds, into which persons condemned toperpetual imprisonment, or to perish secretly, were thrust, or luredto fall.Sudden in the sun An oubliette winks. Where is he Gone. Mrs.Browning.
OBTRUSIONIST: One who practices or excuses obtrusion. [R.] Gent. Mag.
OUTSPEND: Outlay; expenditure. [R.]A mere outspend of savageness. I. Taylor.
OVERLINESS: The quality or state of being overly; carelessness. [Obs.] Bp.Hall.
OPINATOR: One fond of his own opinious; one who holds an opinion. [Obs.]Glanvill.
ODOR: Any smell, whether fragrant or offensive; scent; perfume.Meseemed I smelt a garden of sweet flowers, That dainty odors fromthem threw around. Spenser.To be in bad odor, to be out of favor, or in bad repute.
OXALIC: Pertaining to, derived from, or contained in, sorrel, oroxalis; specifically, designating an acid found in, andcharacteristic of, oxalis, and also certain plant of the Buckwheatfamily. Oxalic acid (Chem.), a dibasic acid, existing combined inoxalis as an acid potassium oxalate, and in many plant tissues as thecalcium oxalate. It is prepared on a large scale, by the action offused caustic soda or potash on sawdust, as a white crystallinesubstance, which has a strong acid taste, and is poisonous in largedoses. It is used in dyeing, calico printing, bleaching flax andstraw, the preparation of formic acid, and in salts of lemon forremoving ink stains, mold, etc.
ODONATA: The division of insects that includes the dragon flies.
OUTBREAST: To surpass in singing. See Breast, n., 6. [Obs.]
OXY-: A prefix, also used adjectively, designating:(a) A compound containing oxygen.(b) A compound containing the hydroxyl group, more properlydesignated by hydroxy-. See Hydroxy-. Oxy acid. See Oxyacid (below).
OCCIDENTALS: Western Christians of the Latin rite. See Orientals. Shipley.
OBLIGING: Putting under obligation; disposed to oblige or do favors;hence, helpful; civil; kind.Mons.Strozzi has many curiosities, and is very obliging to a strangerwho desires the sight of them. Addison.
OBJECT: To make opposition in words or argument; -- usually followed byto. Sir. T. More.
ORTHOTONE: Retaining the accent; not enclitic; -- said of certainindefinite pronouns and adverbs when used interrogatively, which,when not so used, are ordinarilly enclitic.
